It is also essential, for example, to address the problems of press freedom and media pluralism, because in a country dominated by propaganda media, we cannot talk about real democracy. Thank you very much, good luck and good job!

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: – Mr President, I welcome Prime Minister Rinne’s words on unity and sustainability.  But, Prime Minister, you’ll know as I do that words are not enough. We’ve not yet seen evidence that EU leaders have truly heard the voices of those calling for change: the school climate strikers, the extinction rebellion protesters, the millions who voted Green in May. European leaders have been too slow to respond, too keen to conserve the status quo, rather than conserving the planet. We don’t have time to waste, and we can’t go at the pace of the slowest. So I urge you, please, as a first step, deliver on your promise – zero carbon by 2050. Get the Council to put its money where its mouth is and then to increase its level of climate ambition further.  Another big issue facing your Presidency is Brexit. This is not a little local difficulty on the margins. The Brexiteers threaten our common European values. They’re funded by dodgy sources. They don’t care about those left behind. They’ve poisoned our political debate with lies and pandered to extremists. Those of us who are both British and European, who defend fairness, openness and truth, ask you to stand with us together, zusammen, ensemble.  (Applause)

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, it’s good to hear that the Finnish Presidency will prioritise the challenges of climate.  But I think it’s important that we take on board that one of our best options in the fight against climate system breakdown is a dramatic global tree-planting programme that would sequester greenhouse gases. Yet, the Mercosur trade deal will ensure that we speed up the deforestation of the Amazon. Trade deals that facilitate a race to the bottom, in terms of environmental protections and quality standards, are incompatible with meaningful climate action.  The smaller farmers of Ireland and Europe are already finding life difficult. Bringing in cheap food, cheap meat, cheap grain from the Mercosur countries is not the way forward. The farmers that can have the potential to sustainably work farming are being pushed out of existence by trade deals like this.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, Finland is a great country and I think they will have a great Presidency. There are many great colleagues and also a wonderful Commissioner. I have just two questions, one in relation to Brexit. I was very pleased when President von der Leyen, said she was going to honour the Withdrawal Agreement and the backstop, and also be flexible on an extension, if required. Will the Finnish Presidency ensure that the Council are equally flexible, if appropriate? Second question: I’ve been involved in trying to end the biannual clock change for a number of years. We passed a resolution in Parliament and the Commission did a public consultation where over 80% of respondents said they wanted to end it. The next six months are going to be crucial for the Council to make decisions in that regard. Will the Finnish Presidency ensure that the decision of Parliament and the voice of citizens will be respected in that regard?

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Mr President, the European Union is a community of values. We therefore support the Presidency's proposal to strengthen and use the tools for monitoring the rule of law of the European Union. Second ly, Europe must face, and must do so now, important challenges. One way in our power to reduce uncertainty is to work to get this Presidency to close negotiations in the Council on the next multiannual financial framework as early as autumn 2019. Member States need this certainty so that by January 2021 they can have the next financial cycle at the service of citizens, European businesses and the European Union. We support an ambitious and balanced financial framework with the necessary and sufficient flexibility so that the future multiannual financial framework can effectively respond to the Union's political priorities and also to unforeseen circumstances. (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, welcome, Mr President, good luck to the Finnish Presidency. You spoke of a strong Europe, a Europe of security, of human rights. I come from the only European country that has been occupied for 45 years and which is currently under second invasion, and we are talking about European territory and we are talking about Turkey, which wants to become a member of the European family. I want you to always keep that in mind.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want to wish you success. You take over the presidency after the presidency of my country, a successful presidency. I wish you luck! I like what I heard here. You want to take into account the problems of citizens, the single market, very important, I am the Vice-President of the Committee on the Internal Market. You also want security, education, research. It's the things we need. But we need one Europe. Please very much, on your presidency, try not to separate the east-west. Try to make the two states, Romania and Bulgaria, part of Schengen, because they meet these conditions. And I want to ask you something else. You said we need to take citizens into account. I have referred the former Prime Minister of Finland to a very serious case in Finland, the case of Dr. Smimal, with her two children taken and separated from her mother. Try to resolve and set an example that human rights can be respected. Last but not least, I ask you very much to take into account in the negotiation the mobility package and the cohesion fund: we must negotiate them in such a way that we do not split Europe in two.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, a minute simply to denounce the arbitrariness with which the previous president has managed the catch-the-eye interventions. It set two criteria in the end: priority for The Finns and which would not be involved by Members of Member States who had already intervened. I've been there since the first moment and made sure I was enrolled. You have not met the criteria and, of course, I would like to stress that I have been listening from the outing point, and to report that I do not share the criteria and do not share arbitrariness.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: However, I am sorry, the catch-the-eye instrument is an instrument, as you know, which cannot allow everyone to speak, so the choice of President Wieland will have been the one, let us say, suitable for everyone to speak on time.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, as the Prime Minister heard he has strong support for his Presidency agenda from the Members of this House. In particular, two topics were raised in most speeches, namely rule of law and climate policy. Rule of law, or lack of it, is like oxygen: you realise the value of it when it’s running out. As I said in my introductory speech, the Finnish Presidency is the first to prioritise the rule of law, and for good reason. Independent judiciary, free and pluralistic media, human rights and human dignity, democracy – these are the basic values upon which European integration, but also our Member States, have been built. So, even if one wins the majority in the national elections, it does not mean that these fundamental values can be violated. The fact that this is one of the priorities of the Presidency allows this House – the European Parliament – but also the Member States, to take a position on this very fundamental issue. On behalf of the Commission, I want to thank you once again for what you have chosen to prioritise. On climate policy, some Members said – quite well – that, just as important as talking about dates or years or percentages, is to devise ways of how we can achieve our ambitious targets. Here the circular economy comes into the picture. Yesterday I was very pleased personally when the newly elected Commission President von der Leyen said that she will propose a new circular economy action plan that will concentrate mostly on the construction sector and the textile sector, which are resource-consuming sectors where we need to improve our actions.  Finally, from the Commission’s perspective, it’s very positive that the Finnish Presidency makes a new experiment, improving the transparency of the work of the Council. From my own personal viewpoint I’ve been wondering what on earth needs to happen for the other European institutions to follow the example of the European Commission, which is by far the most transparent institution in the EU. I must say that I only have very good experiences of this transparency in the European Commission, so I encourage the other European institutions to follow their example.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this very important opportunity for me to address Parliament on our priorities in the programme. I would say that the big issue for me is climate change. I will now say a few words in Finnish. My friends, I have four daughters and three grandchildren. In Finland, I have spoken several times in which I have said that I would like to answer their question about what you did about climate change, to say that everything that was known and could be done. And that climate change was stopped. The second option is that we did nothing because we were afraid to do anything together.  It is now important that European cooperation should focus on taking leadership in climate policy in a way that will bring global warming on earth to a halt to the 1.5°C that is extremely important from the point of view of mankind as a whole and from the point of view of future generations, and this must be pushed through. I believe, also, that big question of the rule of law is very important for the whole European future. I think that the big issue is that we, together, can make stronger and stronger these rule of law principles when we are developing our cooperation here at European level. Thank you very much and I hope we can work together in future as closely as possible. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Prime Minister, good job. It begins a very important six months that accompanies the beginning of the legislature.  The debate is closed. I call on all my fellow Members to take their place.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am taking the floor because of a very serious event that has happened today.  Ladies and gentlemen, today a great Italian, a great European citizen, Andrea Camilleri, one of the most authoritative contemporary intellectuals, a tenacious defender of the values of freedom, democracy and justice, implacable anti-fascist, a convinced Pro-European, a humble master who has been able to tell, through the episodes of Montalbano, Sicily, a wonderful and generous land, mother of extraordinary men like him.  I am thinking of Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino. Thank you Maestro Camilleri for what you have given us and for representing Italy in the world with your unforgettable writing.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Mr Moretti. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – As a common European project, the European Union unquestionably guarantees peace and prosperity for the peoples of each Member State. Elections to the European Parliament have recently taken place and citizens have made it clear that they are behind the common European project. However, they require us, as their representatives, to make every effort to minimise the impact of climate change and to create the conditions for a clean, energy-efficient and modern economy that will ensure that new jobs are created in the future. The Finnish Presidency has a great opportunity to be involved in creating a better future that is socially, economically but, above all, environmentally sustainable. In the coming months, it will be crucial that we work together to preserve the unity of the European Union, which is destabilised by the so-called Brexit process, and to put an end to this painful process for all parties involved. No less important challenge for the Finnish Presidency will be the issue of edging employee allowances from other Member States of the European Union in Austria, because it is a dangerous presidency of creating a dual category of citizens, which is unacceptable in a modern and competitive Europe. I firmly believe that the Finnish Presidency will also thrive in the smooth transition to the next legislative cycle and in building constructive relations, because only through cooperation can we move the European Union forward together.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – Thank you, I was disappointed to read that the Finnish Presidency's programme did not give the EU enlargement in the Western Balkans a proper place. There is practically only one paragraph on this topic. In contrast, the recent Presidencies of Bulgaria, Austria and Romania have also given priority to this issue. Stability and unity in Europe are key and everyone agrees. However, this requires the accession of the candidate countries of the Western Balkans as soon as possible. Unfortunately, enlargement is not a popular topic in many 'old' Member States, but this should not be a reason why the EU policy that successfully created the unity of the western and eastern half of Europe in 2004 should end up in the category of uncomfortable, pressing issues. I call on the Finnish Presidency to correct this shortcoming at operational level, because it must not cause a rupture in the continuity that has characterised the last two years and of which the European Parliament is one of its biggest supporters.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – We welcome the aspirations of the Finnish Presidency. It is welcome that, in the context of the future of work, they want to examine in detail the situation of platform workers, prioritise continuous lifelong learning and analyse the situation of partially employed persons. I would like to draw attention here to the fact that the integration of persons with disabilities and disabilities into the labour market is a priority issue today, so I am disappointed to see that this is not included in the Presidency's programme, even though their inclusion in the labour market has huge potential and, thanks to assistive technologies, there are fewer and fewer barriers to their employment. Modern responses to labour shortages in our time should be given, but unfortunately this has not succeeded in the Finnish Presidency programme: it is a well-known fact that, in the age of automation and robotics, we need an increasingly skilled workforce and not to help the immigration of low-skilled people. It is surprising that the Finnish Presidency would still support immigration, as statistics show that only a few percent of unskmarked immigrants are able to work in the host country. At the same time, the free movement of labour is a key issue and the EU is one of four freedoms, so it is necessary that CITIZENS of the European Union be allowed to work in other EU Member States indiscriminately. The mobility of eastern European workers must not be undermined by protectionism in the Western European Member States: they are treated the same and cannot be disadvantaged on the labour market by administrative or other measures.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Thanking the Finnish Presidency for its ambitious programme, I am also asking for three issues that are crucial for ensuring justice, social equality and respect for European values. Firstly, it is crucial to agree on a funded framework. We need an ambitious budget that takes into account the significant support for cohesion and agricultural policy. In this context, I call on the Finnish Presidency to actively support the European Parliament's position on the POST-2020 EU budget, which provides for more resources for agriculture and regional development. Secondly, action is important to put the European minimum wage at a level that ensures a decent life for all Europeans. The current differences in this respect between Member States are unacceptable. The European minimum wage is crucial for reducing inequalities between EU citizens, eradicating poverty and ensuring a level playing field.  Thirdly, I am pleased that the rule of law is an important part of the Presidency's agenda. That is why I support the planned actions in this area. However, I would like to draw attention to a prudent approach to linking respect for the rule of law to expenditure from the EU budget. We must not allow the governments of the Member States to pay young people, scientists, farmers or other groups of beneficiaries of EU funds who profess our European values and who hope for a better tomorrow in the Union for non-compliance with the law.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – 1 July Finland takes over the Presidency of the Council of the EU from Romania. The initial identification of the most important activities was aligned with the Romanian programme, which gives hope for the continuity of Community policies in this difficult period for Europe. Perhaps Finland will succeed in this task, which I wish it to do. Finland inherited a number of outstanding current issues from its predecessors, such as Brexit or the need to continue its efforts to make the EU more internationally and further promote the social situation. But, in my opinion, there is a lack of things: a mention of the values that were based on a united Europe. I am referring to the Christian values that the founding fathers have spoken about, and which today's Union forgets to undermine itself. Therefore, in order to achieve a fairer EU, where all citizens can enjoy the benefits of economic and social development, it is important to respect the right world and to return to the roots of a Europe based on the vision of Robert Schuman or Alcide de Gasperi. It is therefore necessary to return to the principles rooted in European identity. It is also necessary to ensure the security of EU citizens in order to improve migration policy, including control of the EU's external borders. However, it is also important to try to reduce inequalities in EU countries. This is particularly awaited by the populations of the new Member States, such as Lithuania.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. We welcome the Finnish Presidency's programme, with its focus on the important issues of climate change, human rights and strengthening the rule of law. The incoming Presidency's ambition to make Europe more social and sustainable has long been a key demand of the European Greens.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on humanitarian aid in the Mediterranean (2019/2718(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I will continue on from what the Prime Minister mentioned in his speech this morning. We need a long-term, comprehensive and humane solution to manage migration.  Even though the generally known problems remain, as the debate today will certainly show, we should also note that, in broad terms, the situation of migration flows in the Mediterranean Sea has improved in recent years. According to Frontex data for 2018, approximately 137 000 irregular migrants were registered, having crossed the Mediterranean via one of the three main routes. This year, so far, we are at 36 000 arrivals. Should this trend continue, we would see the number of detected arrivals reduced by approximately 50% in 2019.  Equally important, while of course it is still too high, the number of deaths at sea has decreased. On the central Mediterranean route alone, the decrease is by more than 50%. In 2019, 343 persons are known to have lost their lives while attempting to cross the sea via this route. Any death at sea is one too many, but there is progress. UNHCR estimates that in 2018, the Libyan coast guard rescued or intercepted nearly 15 000 migrants at sea. Even with the deteriorating security situation in Libya this year, the coast guard has continued functioning, rescuing nearly 3 000 persons. These numbers also reflect the important contribution of the EU’s action to reduce fatalities at sea. In particular, in Libya, assistance has been of paramount importance. EUR 91.3 million were granted to support both the Libyan coast guard and the development of Libya’s own maritime rescue coordination centre. Further, Operation Sophia has provided training for a total of 355 coast guard personnel so far and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) has provided training on access to the asylum procedure. These are very concrete steps forward.  There is no denying that the humanitarian situation surrounding the search—and—rescue events on the central Mediterranean route is still not satisfactory. Also, stand-offs between Member States continue as a result of NGO vessels picking up migrants at sea. Let me point out that against the overall background, the number of migrants involved in these incidents is quite modest. In 2019, less than 10% of migrants who arrived in Italy had been rescued by NGOs active on the central Mediterranean route. The vast majority of migrants arrived directly in Lampedusa and Sicily or they were rescued by vessels of the Italian authorities. However, in recent weeks, there have been more incidents due to the peak in departures at this time of the year. One example is the Sea-Watch 3. In its case, solutions have been found after one or two weeks or on an ad hoc basis.  The Romanian Presidency has worked on temporary arrangements which would make it possible to manage this type of situation in a more structured manner. In 2019, it presented a report with a series of non-binding elements on temporary arrangements for this embarkation. Our Presidency will continue work on temporary arrangements. An informal meeting of ministers of the interior will take place on Thursday and the situation in the Mediterranean will be highlighted there. Our Minister of the Interior has also invited all her ministerial colleagues to an informal dinner ahead of this meeting to discuss this immediate situation in the Mediterranean. They are temporary in nature until a permanent agreement is found as part of a comprehensive and humane asylum—policy reform. They are open to participation by all Member States on a voluntary basis and provide for a coordination role for the Commission, with support from relevant agencies. This moves towards more balanced responsibility. Solidarity between the Member States is key. The Finnish Presidency will follow up on this work.  The Finnish Presidency will work towards crisis—resilient arrangements. While these arrangements provide some guidance on how to deal with migrants rescued at sea, they do not pronounce on the location where there is embarkment. Human rights—based asylum and migration policies are rooted in international treaties and conventions, cooperation between public authorities and effective control of the EU’s external borders, as well as appropriate and swift asylum procedures that are of a high standard in terms of legal protection. This is by and large a decision for national authorities in application of the relevant provisions under international law. International law obliges all coastal states – in our case, all coastal states around the Mediterranean Sea – to establish search—and—rescue services around their coast. The EU provides support to Member States in the management of their external borders, notably through Frontex operations. Search—and—rescue is not as such the core mandate of these operations, but it is the task they perform in accordance with international law.  The Finnish Presidency will certainly look into ways to unlock the situation. Nobody benefits from this prolonged uncertainty. We need a balanced, comprehensive and humane approach here. Firstly, we need to help the front-liners but, at the same time, we need to understand the challenge as a whole in the secondary movement and integration of migrants, as well as in return policy. The European Union, with its wide range of tools and strong international role, is clearly better equipped to address migration than a single Member State.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am here on behalf of Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos. There is no doubt that what is happening in the Mediterranean is a cause for high concern. But at the same time, official figures show that flows to the EU have further diminished compared to last year. My dear colleague, the Finnish Minister, has already shown some of these figures. But there is no doubt that we still face a critical situation where too many people embark on dangerous journeys across the sea, risking their lives, in the hope of reaching the EU for protection or better life prospects. This is why the Commission has repeatedly recalled that the EU and its Member States are bound by the duty to render assistance to persons or vessels in distress at sea, which is an obligation under international law – and, may I also add, our moral duty. For their part, NGOs active in the Mediterranean have played an important role in saving lives at sea. In serving this common objective of saving lives, all players should follow the instructions received from the national authority coordinating search and rescue operations. Allow me to say that our four EU operations at sea have helped save nearly 730 000 people at sea since 2015, though we regret that the agreement found by Member States for the continuation of Operation Sophia is far from optimal. When it comes to the question of criminalisation of migrant smuggling, we need to be able to distinguish. Because one thing is actual migrant smuggling, a deliberate profit-making criminal act, and another is providing assistance to people in need. The bottom line here – and I want to underline this – is that no form of genuine assistance to migrants should be criminalised under EU law. However, the essence is that a system whereby people must resort to smugglers cannot be part of a sustainable approach to migration or asylum. The European Union and its Member States must remain resolute to keep on fighting against migrant smugglers and traffickers and not to play into their deadly business model. The most recent atrocious killing of migrants at the Tajoura Detention Centre is a strong reminder of the need to continue to pursue the EU’s efforts to protect the most vulnerable and to put an end to the Libyan arbitrary detention system. The European Union stands ready to support the Libyan authorities to find safe and dignified alternatives for all refugees and other migrants in detention centres close to the conflict area. And let us not forget our overall assistance to Libya, which goes beyond EUR 365 million this year. Thanks to our funding and partnership with IOM and UNHCR, since 2017 more than 40 000 migrants stranded in Libya have been assisted to voluntarily return to their countries of origin while 4 000 refugees have been already evacuated from Libya to Niger or directly to Europe in view of their resettlement. In early July, a further EUR 13 million was granted to UNHCR to reinforce evacuation operations. For these evacuations towards Niger to continue, Member States must speed up resettlements and pledge more resettlement places for persons in Libya or for evacuees in Niger. Despite all these efforts to intervene upstream on the migratory route, we cannot avoid that under certain circumstances, disembarkations take place in Europe. We must be ready to address this situations and, as my dear colleague the Finnish Minister already said, the most fundamental thing is solidarity. While search and rescue remains a national competence, exercised on the basis of international law, the Commission has played a coordinating role to ensure that, when disembarkation takes place in Europe, solidarity is implemented. However, ad hoc solutions cannot be sustainable. We need to put in place predictable temporary arrangements following disembarkation based on a practical and voluntary approach, supported by the EU operationally and financially. They will serve as a bridge until the swift completion of the legislative reform of the Common European Asylum System, which remains a priority for all of us. I welcome the fact that on Monday, Ministers of Foreign Affairs discussed the situation in the Mediterranean. This discussion will be taken forward by the Ministers of External Affairs later today, as my dear colleague Finnish Minister already emphasised. Commissioner Avramopoulos is on his way to Helsinki to discuss with them the way forward to put in place temporary arrangements following disembarkation, built on shared responsibility as part of a broader discussion on the future of the EU asylum and migration policy. The Commission stands ready to continue to provide all the political, technical and financial support that Member States need to address the situation in the Mediterranean. And let us not forget the overarching need to deal with the root causes of migration in parallel with our efforts to help save lives. Africa is a huge challenge – not only for Europe, but also the world. The Juncker Commission has done a lot in this direction. First, through the EU Trust Fund. Second, with the External Investment Plan that has leveraged EUR 37 billion of investments. And third, with the EU-Africa Alliance, through which we aim to create 10 million jobs in Africa in the next five years. Of course, we have to continue. This is the only way to deal with the root causes. We have to create new jobs in Africa, but at the same time, we have to continue our moral duty to save lives.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this feels a little bit like Groundhog Day. We’re debating the same issue, in the same way, just on a different day. We discussed it in June last year after the Aquarius, we discussed it in January of this year after Sea—Watch and Sea—Eye, and today we are discussing it again. On both previous occasions we were told, as we are today, no more ad hoc solutions. And cynically, in the case of Sea—Watch, the Member States kept their word. There was no ad hoc solution – there was no solution at all. And that is a sad reality for an EU that is based on fundamental values and the principle of solidarity. I agree with the Commissioner: saving lives is not only a legal obligation but a moral one, too. But at the same time we have to realise that the current way in which we are working in the Mediterranean, despite all good intentions, is not only helping to save lives but, at the same time, it unfortunately helps the smugglers who put those lives at risk in the first place. This is something we can no longer allow. There is no silver bullet or single solution to all this. We need a holistic approach – an approach that focuses on better protecting our external borders, that focuses on returning migrants who came illegally to Europe and have no right to stay and an approach that focuses on making agreements with third countries of transit and of origin to help us fight those smuggling networks and to help us prevent migrants from entering in overstuffed and unseaworthy vehicles. Such an approach is the only approach in the long term that can actually save lives.

name: Miriam DALLI

(Il-President irtira l-kelma flower-kelliema)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Council and the Commission for their very clear commitment to finding sustainable solutions because sometimes I feel a little bit like I am in the twilight zone. There used to be a time where it was considered the morally right thing to do to save people from drowning and to provide shelter to the vulnerable and to refugees. That’s even a Christian duty. I’m not Christian, but I was taught that this is the right thing to do. But now we are actually talking about criminalising saving people. I actually think it’s a criminal act to let somebody drown. Those who are in favour of criminalising it say, ‘these NGOs who are saving people in the Mediterranean are creating a pull factor’. Well, sorry, what they want is a deterrent. They think that if those boats cannot come here, that’s a deterrent. Well, if 35 000 dead bodies on the bottom of the Mediterranean is not a deterrent, then what is? We are talking about small vessels bringing in 40-50 people. I think the Union can handle that. I think that this is not a responsibility that we should put on the shoulders of NGOs or commercial vessels, which are also burdened with this. This is a public responsibility. It is also a collective responsibility for all the EU Member States. It is unacceptable that our Member States still to this day refuse to take their share of the responsibility. We need a sustainable arrangement, not a temporary arrangement. We also call on the Council to finally adopt the asylum package and then, finally, we also need to get real and stop fighting symptoms. We need migration. Migration exists, it has existed since the beginning of time, we should manage it, we should control it, and we should create legal and safe pathways for legal labour migration to Europe.  (Applause)

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It is happiness that decides where you are born on this planet, and it is happiness that determines whether you can grow up in peace and prosperity, or whether you have to grow up in misery. I myself was on the Mediterranean as a rescuer, and I saw the suffering there. And I still can't imagine what it feels like to be sitting on a small inflatable boat and not knowing if you will survive the next day. I can't imagine what it feels like if you can't swim. And all you want is air, and you can't find it because there's water everywhere. And you look for something to hold on to it and you can't find it, because there's only water there. And then you drown in the Mediterranean, quietly, in agony.  I want to be proud of what we are doing as Europeans, but I can only be ashamed of the moment that thousands of people drown in the Mediterranean, which we could save, but also when European values drown in the Mediterranean. It is so easy to prevent dying. There are more than 70 municipalities in Germany alone that have agreed to take in people. Let's let them! And if there are laws that punish life-saving more than letting them die, let's change those laws. And if there are boats that can save, let's send these boats damn again. It would be a sign of strength to say that human dignity is inviolable, even in the Mediterranean. (Applause)

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This is the second time that I have been a Member of this House and I have seen how, since 2015, when the migration wave began, there is no solution here to deal with this problem, nor are we somehow approaching a better state. On the contrary, you are sending the wrong signals in permanence and are thus also fulfilling the business of smugglers. And please don't talk about sea rescue. If a person like Mrs Carola Rackete – whatever her name may be saying – takes people 20 kilometres from the Libyan coast, takes hundreds of kilometres to Italy, violates one law after another, illegally invades Italian territorial waters, endangers the lives of Italian officials by pushing their ship, then this is not a sea rescue, but a political action with a series of legal offences. , which must be evaluated in this way here. This is not an icon, it is not a saint, it is a lawbreaker. This must be made very clear here. (Applause)

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask you straight away a question: what is the border between the rescue at sea of human lives that are really at risk and the behaviour of those who transport people from one side of the Mediterranean to another, making a mockery of the law?  I'm telling you. The first is a lawful, generous, obviously impromptu and harmless act. The second is a politically planned act, deliberately repeated, which puts the safety of migrants at risk and is therefore also a criminal act. I do not support it, the ECR or Fratelli d'Italia does not support it, it supports the law, international law, the one to which you often appeal in an often opportunistic way.  We are now allowing captains of fortune without any popular mandate to claim the right to spur both physically and metaphorically the dignity of our nations, the peace of our nations. We are abandoning the rule of law at sea, just what we were talking about here yesterday. So let us arm ourselves with courage, but also with means to stop clandestine departures, dismantle the ships that are taxis and save more lives in the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we say this once again: the European Union and the Member States have to choose between protecting life or remaining complicit in death; remain complicit in turning the Mediterranean into a great mass grave. Breaking with this European migration policy of death means to stop criminalizing all those people and organisations that save lives. Saving lives can never be a crime. Breaking with Salvini's macabre game, which uses death to win votes, also means urgently launching – urgently - a public maritime save from the European Union so that there is not one more death in the Mediterranean. It means supporting all civil society initiatives that are struggling to change immigration policy and are doing so right now with the Caravan Opening initiative... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker) (Group ID whistles)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, migratory flows in the Mediterranean have decreased, but in fact people continue to leave and die.  In dealing with migration, we have long been waiting for a strong and cohesive European and international response. An answer that has not yet arrived. Unfortunately, selfish national policies have prevailed, leaving only some of the Member States to manage migratory flows, with an emergency solution, on a case-by-case basis and with a propaganda market that divides people and countries and creates monsters and heroes.  It is recent that Minister Moavero has presented a plan for a European solution. It is a question of saving lives and identifying landing sites, of establishing automatic and compulsory relocations for migrants, of combating the business of human trafficking in the Mediterranean, of providing legal avenues for those entitled to international protection, of cooperating in the areas of origin of the flows affected by conflicts, poverty, exploitation of resources, and of concluding readmission agreements for returns.  These are issues that cannot be dealt with only by first-port countries such as Italy, Malta, Spain or Greece, but the whole of the European Union must take responsibility for them. The lack of a common position among all the Member States on the fair distribution of responsibilities in European asylum and immigration policies, as well as mortifying the principles contained in the Treaties, undermines the credibility of the European project, and that is why I hope that, with the restart of this parliamentary term, the work done by this Parliament on the reform of the common European asylum system will be resumeed.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, here in the European Parliament, it is customary for us to be complaining and critical of everyone. I will use this time to give credit to the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management before us who really found himself as the representative of the European Union in every corner of the world, where there was human suffering, providing humanitarian aid and support. In this way it gave substance and upgrading to the European Union, making us all often proud, because the European Union through itself has never been absent from any humanitarian crises. He was always present and gave a real helping hand, highlighting the humanitarian and social role of the European Union.  I would even like to ask: The other major powers – because we usually turn the fire on the European Union – what did they do for the Mediterranean, what did they do about the humanitarian crisis, how much money they gave or what actions and initiatives they took? The European Union certainly requires and requires unity and solidarity, and when we say unity and solidarity, we must not let these issues be addressed by each country alone, but we must all deal with them together. (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, someone mentioned international law just now. It is not against international law to seek asylum or indeed to seek a better life. What is happening in the Mediterranean, despite what we have heard from the Council about the numbers who are dying reducing, is an assault against human dignity in the Mediterranean and a challenge to our European values. I think we can all agree with this, so let’s not discuss exactly how international law applies. What is applying now is a real confusion and an ammunition given to some on the question of the criminalisation of humanitarian assistance. And let’s be clear: the human instinct, the European instinct, the global instinct to aid people who may be dying, as we have just heard, is one that we need to clarify and we need to accept as one of our values. One year ago exactly I drafted a resolution, as the Commissioner will know, asking exactly what guidelines we would have to prevent humanitarian assistance from being criminalised. Of course, we were told then that there were not many cases. Now we see the cases. With regard to Sea—Watch 3, we see many cases now of criminalisation of humanitarian assistance. So exactly when are these guidelines going to be issued? When are we going to see them? Over the last year we have seen the odyssey, not just of Sea—Watch, but just ordinary individuals, these are not criminals these are just the people we know – doctors, lifeguards, firefighters – all the people who are European citizens trying to save lives. And finally, colleagues, for the Council. What I would say to the Council is this: of course we need to have the guidelines, of course we need to deal with the humanitarian situation in the Mediterranean, so we can look in the eyes people in the coming years and say we did something about this disgrace that is going on in the Mediterranean and the fuel that we are giving to some politicians to use this issue. Also for the Council, how on earth are we going to get the Dublin process and solidarity sorted out if we don’t have majority voting and qualified majority voting (QMV) and the things that I have to ask the Finnish Presidency to make some progress on? We need Dublin. We need the common asylum policy. We need ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: – Mr President, as another colleague said earlier, we’ve been in this debate for four years. I know that as a union we’ve done a lot under challenging circumstances. The Commission has made great efforts and put forward bold solutions, and on this side, this House has played its part in a spirit of institutional loyalty and competence. But all this said, here we are four years later still holding our breath every time there is a boat in the Mediterranean waters, and then the game of ad hoc, half-baked measures is starting. Will they go to Italy? Will they go to Malta? Will they go to Spain? And whose responsibility is it? We simply cannot afford politically to continue this way. We simply cannot afford to let our European citizens be haunted by a moral dilemma between protecting lives and good management of migration flows. The two are possible together, the two can go hand in hand. Solidarity and responsibility can and must co-exist.  We need structured solutions – and I took good note of the promise of the commitment made yesterday by the new Commission President to a migration pact. That is good, but until that pact is going to happen, we need the Council to support the scale—up of Frontex without delay because Frontex has to be back in the Mediterranean waters as quickly as possible and at full strength. (Applause)

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Mr President, at sea every minute counts and that is why the Law of the Sea obliges every actor to immediately assist people in distress and to disembark them at the first safe haven. However, our Member States ignore these obligations and on top of that, they also work against NGOs which do save lives. And instead of ensuring safety and protection they organise unlawful pull-backs to Libya, where migrants are exposed to violence, inhuman treatment in detention centres and to the risk of refoulement.  We need to stop these shameful violations of international law close to our borders. We need to act united and in solidarity and that means more capacity for search-and-rescue actions at EU level and equally shared responsibility for rescued persons who ask for asylum, not ad hoc but on a sustainable basis. It also means that we need to ensure that refugees have access to safe routes and durable protection and we welcome the announcement from Ms von der Leyen on human corridors. But finally, acknowledging our responsibility for the drownings in the Mediterranean also requires that we ensure that the human rights of migrants and refugees are not affected as a consequence of our cooperation with Libya. So it means that we need to scrutinise the EU budget that we invest in cooperation with Libya to check it does not affect their human rights. After all, out of sight does not mean out of rights.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday in this House the statement that 'lives must be saved at sea', which has been reiterated today, was followed by enormous applause from almost all of Parliament. That applause – I repeat – only goes to Italy, which has saved thousands of lives in the Mediterranean. The Italy it has welcomed, Italy which, on the other hand, has been left alone by Europe and by those who today, with great hypocrisy, allow themselves to criticise the government's policy to combat illegal immigration.  We wonder what you have done in recent years, what has France done, for example? Today she announced that she wanted to reward Carola Rackete, but she was careful not to respond to her SOS at sea. So the French ports closed, but medals open... once again a great hypocrisy that I find embarrassing! The truth is that only our government and only Minister Salvini with great courage and against all kinds of insults, is trying to stop the business of slave holders and illegal immigration, saving lives.  The policy of closed ports has allowed fewer landings, the ones you mentioned, fewer deaths in the Mediterranean, and the League does not say so, but the UN figures say so. And again, rather than judging by foreign allologists, come to Italy, come to Sicily, to Lampedusa, you will see in what desperate conditions we try to stem an epochal phenomenon that conveys many different problems. It is the responsibility of this Parliament and the Council to help those who are entitled to it, but legally and safely, over and above the proclamations, those we have heard and continue to hear. We expect real and immediate action. Our citizens are tired of...  (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, as a Spanish Member, I can assure you that the most effective way to stop the possible death of people in the Mediterranean is the relentless fight against illegal immigration and against all those who collaborate and cooperate in this trafficking in human beings. Only the possibility of creating a European framework for preventing and combating illegal trafficking in human beings can actually save lives. The so-called effect is a reality and is an unacceptable irresponsibility of those governments and political groups that continue to encourage thousands of people in Africa to set out on a deadly journey in the Mediterranean, with the collaboration of these illegal human trafficking mafias and their necessary co-operators. The borders of the Union must be an impassable gateway for all those who wish to enter the territory of the Union in breach of Community laws or national laws. And that is why we cannot accept that, from the Community institutions, the actions of those captains who want to continue to illegally bring human beings with breach of our national and Community legislation will be encouraged.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Mr President, more than 2,200 people died in the Mediterranean Sea in 2018. They are not accidents: they are a direct consequence of the policies of the strong Europe. A few days ago, we were joined here by the lawyers who have brought the European Union before the Prosecutor's Office of the International Criminal Court, precisely because of these migration policies responsible for more than 14,000 deaths. This can't go unpunished. There is a chain of political, administrative and implementation responsibility. In this sense, from the European United Left we propose concrete solutions. In the face of the resignation of government functions, this Parliament must commit to creating a civilian rescue and rescue mission at sea. And, of course, it must break with the criminalization of the life-defense efforts being carried out by NGOs, in many cases in the face of reactionary and neo-brazilian governments. Saving lives is not a crime. Let's get them to close ports and fine those who save them.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union and its governments, their allies and their politics are responsible for the imperialist wars and the waves of refugees and migrants. The wretched current situation against them is unanimously decided by all governments in the European Councils. President von der Leyen's announcements to increase the Euro-border guard to 10,000 signals an intensity of repression against refugees and more refugee deaths in the Mediterranean.  In Greece, the New Democracy government continues to promote the European Union's inhumane policy against refugees and migrants, co-ed and promoted by the SYRIZA government in accordance with European Union-Turkey-type agreements, strengthening border repression, deportations and criminal refusals to rescue refugees at sea, by governments of Member States. The entrapment in Moria-type hells, stamped by SYRIZA, is now being praised by the New Democracy government, which is bidding on new reactionary measures, such as the transfer of responsibilities to the Ministry of Citizen Protection and the callous withdrawal of this already limited access of refugees and asylum seekers to health care.  We are fighting against the European Union-Turkey agreement, to immediately close all the wretched hot spots, to transport refugees and migrants to their final destination countries, against Schengen and Dublin, against all these unpopular laws, against the system of exploitation and imperialist wars.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Recent events show that this debate is necessary, but we must finally conduct it honestly. As a former judge and human rights activist, I say to you: of course we must save people from certain death in the Mediterranean, but we still have much more than that to do, we must finally remove the incentives to flee. We must prevent people from getting on the boats. Actions that receive a lot of media attention are happening at the moment. Hopes are being stoked, people are being tricked into getting on the boats. Only to learn shortly after arrival that there is no reason for asylum. The rescue, often just a few kilometres off the African coast, cannot mean the ticket to Europe. As Europeans, we must finally take this matter into our own hands and really discuss it relentlessly, seek solutions and initiate a sustainable reform of the asylum procedure here. If we care about the stability and the survival of Europe, then it is our duty to put solutions in place now.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Humanity in the Mediterranean. For far too long, the Council has been blocking a reform of the common asylum system, including the Dublin Regulation. The rescue of the sea in the Mediterranean was stopped and thus a contemptuous game was played with those seeking protection, inability to take action on the backs of people. Refugees are being pushed back to Libya for human trafficking, torture and forced labour. And in order to enforce this perfidious game, Member States are criminalising those who save lives and doing what is actually the task of the Member States – all Member States. The European Union - a community of values? The Commission, too, remains guilty of clarifications, such as a revision of the aid directive to provide legal certainty to aid workers. Saving lives is not a crime, sea rescue is not human trafficking! The Commission must also act. Yesterday, Mrs von der Leyen spoke in flowery terms of a reboot of the asylum system. Restart? We now need a legislative proposal on humanitarian visas and contributions to binding resettlement requirements as soon as possible. These, too, would be contributions to an orderly migration and refugee policy. Moreover, this House has already found a broad majority in favour of shared responsibility, including the distribution of refugees. The European Parliament has done its job, we have taken majority decisions to respond to the challenges. This must now finally be implemented!

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, Mrs Tytti Tuppurainen, thank you for your commitment, thank you too, Commissioner Christos Stylianides. Ursula von der Leyen said yesterday morning that no one should die in the Mediterranean Sea. You, like me, share this goal. NGOs are currently the main actors in this humanitarian aid and they are of course partners. But, as my colleague Drago Tudorache said earlier, we must, Europe must take matters into its own hands as well. As we well know, as has already been said, the question is the need for solidarity between the countries of the Union to ensure the rescue at sea of those who embark on migratory routes, sometimes at the risk of their lives. As we know, it is currently a few states that receive the majority of migrants and who must, in fact, take care of them. We need to reform our asylum policy. The urgent need now is to provide a temporary mechanism to ensure this humanitarian assistance. So here are my questions, Madam Minister, Commissioner: first, how can the European Union act to achieve this humanitarian objective quickly? The second question is that the Frontex agency rescues tens of thousands of people a year at sea, as you have reminded. How do you plan to strengthen its role, with what means?

name: Magid MAGID
text: – Mr President, the future of Europe will be defined by courage or cowardice, by compassion or callousness, by hope or fear. Carola Rackete, Captain of the Sea-Watch 3, courageously sailed into the depths of the Mediterranean cemetery to snatch her fellow humans from the jaws of death. In this, she is a living embodiment of a fairer, kinder Europe, and our fellow brothers and sisters crossing the Mediterranean deserve more than just a statement. They deserve the openness of our arms, the safety of our welcomes, and the warmth of our European embraces. In contrast, Matteo Salvini is a coward. A coward because what kind of grown man watches a child drowning, gasping for breath and turns his back? (Jeers from the ID Group) A coward who boasts about detaining and arresting a lifesaver. A coward who decides to make an enemy of the victims of war and those who have been dispossessed. To Salvini and all his supporters who I can see here: you are all going to lose, I promise you that, because at the end of the day those who have courage in their hearts and want to succeed – we are going to win. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Magid. Apart from the fact that it is customary for us to stand up when you talk about what you have done – perhaps I am a little old-fashioned – I would be very attached to you if you would consider taking off your headgear when you speak. (Unrest in the hall and applause)

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was not a Member of the European Parliament, I was already working here for the League and I notice that so many debates of this kind have taken place, and I do not believe that we will have solved the problem this evening.  I note, however, that there were 6 Members of the League, now there are 28, our group was 37 Members, now there are 73. Perhaps some of you have not understood what the solution is, but I am not addressing the left, I am addressing our friends in the PPE who I think are very confused, who I believe want to govern this Europe together with people who say these things, together with people who continue to make a speech that is not right or wrong, it is totally unrealistic and unreal. If today there are no deaths, or rather, there are fewer deaths than those of a few years ago, we owe it to the activity of Matteo Salvini, to the activity of the Coast Guard, the Navy and the Guardia di Finanza. Instead, we are witnessing the hypocrisy, the hypocrisy of those who, like the current French government – we have many friends in France who think the same way as we do – but the French government prevents Mrs Rackete from arriving in Marseilles, arrests those who bring immigrants from Italy to France, but then in Paris rewards Mrs Rackete or tries to destabilise Italy historically since they decided and insisted , still in Sarkozy's time, for military intervention in Libya.  So what are we talking about? We are talking about economic migrants, the only solution is that of repatriations. Commissioner Avramopoulos tried and you have watered down that directive, we have to work on that, otherwise we will have ...  (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, irregular migration in the Mediterranean is a challenge that some Member States face on a daily basis, often without the particular assistance of a Union that remains paralysed by particular interests, worldview squabbles and bureaucratic problems. Rescuing migrants at sea is our moral obligation, there must be no dispute about this, but the fact is that it encourages migrants to try to enter Europe illegally to some extent and encourages irresponsible behaviour that endangers lives. The solution to this situation is not to abandon the rescue of migrants, as such a thing would be inhumane and against everything the Union stands for, but rather better cooperation with the authorities of African countries. We need to make sure that rescued migrants are returned to African soil, but that's where our concern doesn't stop. They must be returned to a safe environment in which their human rights will be respected. This will discourage illegal migration, ensure respect for international law and order, but also protect people's lives, health and dignity.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am standing here to bow to the dead migrants in the Mediterranean and at the EU's external borders. In front of their families, in front of their friends, in front of their parents, in front of children, in front of the elderly, in front of boys.  We are talking about 40 000 people who are believed to have died, captured by NGOs. 40 000 people. There is not even official EU statistics on the deaths we have in the Mediterranean or anywhere else at the EU's external borders. There is no such thing, and I tell you, I think that human dignity is the minimum, the least that is to be recorded as a dead person. We owe that to these people, ladies and gentlemen.  And I am here to thank those who, despite Salvini, despite Seehofer and their consorts and as they are all called, save lives. Like the crew of Sea-Watch, Mission Lifeline, Youth Rescue, Sea-Eye, these are heroes for me, I want to say that. And why? Because they defend the right to life, and I also tell you, no human being ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Athanasios KONSTANTINOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that the problem of the proper provision of humanitarian aid should be tackled by a single specific fixed mechanism, universally accepted by all the Member States of the Union. The Mediterranean is an area of activity for people seeking refuge in Europe, in Europe as a whole and not especially in one of its own country. The solution to the humanitarian issue of migration must therefore be shaped in a European context.  The resumption of European naval operations in the Mediterranean Sea, according to the UN proposal, since 2014, the distribution of refugees to member countries on clear objective criteria, the drastic use of European offices outside the European Union, where asylum requests from Member States will be made and the air transport of asylum seekers to Europe are potential essential pillars of genuine humanitarian support. With an active system of this type, involving European countries adequately, unfortunate human beings will be rescued from criminal traffickers as well as from maritime dangers.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, I want it to be very clear and clear that the right to life is always ahead of any of our conceptions on asylum, refugees, migration flows or border control. Life is at the forefront of these conceptions and I understand states such as Cyprus, Malta, Greece, Italy, Spain, which have to face these vacancies and which need our help and solidarity.  It was because we are not sympathetic to these States, because we are not solving the problem of distribution at European level, that phenomena such as Salvini have arisen, hostility and discrimination and, since I am talking about Salvini, I would like to say here that it is absolutely absurd that there should be a young Portuguese, his name is Miguel Duarte, who is on trial in Italy for saving lives in the Mediterranean. Anyone who saves lives in the Mediterranean should not be tried, is not committing a crime, is preventing crimes.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Stylianides, we are again debating humanitarian aid in the Mediterranean. Isn't it tremendous that we debated it a hundred times in the last parliamentary term and that we discussed it again in the last plenary session of the last parliamentary term, and that we should discuss it again in this first plenary session of the new mandate of the European Parliament? The reason is simple, and it is that there are undoubtedly aspects in the tragedy in the Mediterranean that escape even the enormous work that you have done in your police station, as is the case with the demographic explosion in Africa and the tortured neighborhood on the southern shore of the Mediterranean. But this Parliament has demanded from the Commission and the Council what depends on Europe. To begin with, to change the look, because it is the absence of legal avenues of access to the European Union that means that anyone who wants to try, fleeing persecution or hunger, has to risk their lives by putting the ourselves in the hands of criminal organisations exploiting people, and particularly the most vulnerable: defenceless women and girls. But we also demand that this response be European, respectful of international humanitarian law, of European law itself — Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which requires solidarity. Because the answer cannot be Malta, it cannot be Italy, it cannot be Greece, nor can it be Spain, but it has to be a common European response. That is why we call on the Council, as soon as possible, to unlock the Treaty, the Dublin Regulation and the asylum package, to meet the European Parliament's mandate to establish legal avenues of access to the European Union, including humanitarian visas. And we call on the Commission to implement as soon as possible the reform of the scandalous Aid Directive, which allows the criminalisation of humanitarian aid. Because we have said many times that humanitarian aid provided at sea by vessels such as Sea-Watch or As Open Arms can in no case be criminalized, nor can such persons be prosecuted or prosecuted or seated on the bench of a court or criminal court. Because saving lives at sea is not a crime; because the work carried out by the cooperators, doctors or captains or captains of those vessels, such as Carola Rackete, can in no case lead them to a criminal trial. Changing the humanitarian gaze, establishing legal avenues for access to the European Union, reforming the Aid Directive so that it is no longer possible to criminalise and making life-saving at sea a crime is the urgent task. Let's not have to debate it a hundred times in this legislature again! Let's get to work as soon as possible! The Finnish Presidency has affirmed its commitment and we take the floor to ensure that, as soon as possible, the Dublin Regulation is unlocked, the Common European Asylum System is completed, the Aid Directive reformed, and we do not have to remain in this psalm, which ritually mourns deaths at sea in every plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Our European values require us to help people in distress at sea. It is our humanitarian duty to help at this point. I find it downright shameful that we, as the European Union, are dependent on private organisations to do so. I think it is our responsibility as the European Union for us to act there. That is why I think that we urgently need a new maritime rescue mission in the Mediterranean to help people in distress at sea. We must bring these people, which we then pick up, to a safe haven. And Let me make it clear here that Libya is not such a safe haven today. In addition to a safe haven, we must then work with the UNHCR to find solutions for more resettlement, for clear rules on migration, for a better uniform asylum system in Europe with high standards of the rule of law and humanitarian. That is the way in which we can prevent these people from making their way into the boat, to the Mediterranean. That is what we must achieve, so that the desperation that these people have disappears.

name: Magid MAGID
text: – Madam President, on a point of order I just want to point out my frustration, in all honesty, with the previous President for telling me to take my hat off when there’s clearly no procedural rules meaning I have to take my hat off, while at the same time not calling on certain Members to be quiet when they were shouting. So can you please pass on the message to the previous President to concentrate on chairing the meeting and not so much what people are wearing? (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: We will examine this dress matter together with the President. But it is quite true that there should be no hendings here. You all have the speaking time requested, and I would ask you to stick to them.

name: Damien CARÊME
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in Lampedusa, with Dr Pietro Bartolo, who is next to me, I have seen death in the tetanus eyes of the newly saved exiles. In Grande-Synthe, in my city, among the thousands of Kurds I welcomed, I heard the plight of Mustapha, a Syrian, telling me how the smugglers threw overboard frightened passengers. In Tarifa, I felt the terror when we swam across the Strait of Gibraltar and the rescuers formally forbade it for us because it was too dangerous. Yet, every day, many of them try this impossible bet. In Strasbourg today, I wonder where our humanity has gone? I am appalled by this Europe which refuses to take responsibility for history. I am furious at the so-called political 'responsible' who would rather let the Mediterranean become an open-air graveyard than act by launching a European rescue mission at sea now! But it's a top priority! The only thing Ursula von der Leyen promises us is a "more sustainable approach to search and rescue." This jargon is undignified because the reality is that human beings are drowning every day and that Europe is doing nothing! It's time for that to change!

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, in the Mediterranean, NGOs picking up illegal immigrants from Libyan territorial waters on board their ships do not do humanitarian activities, but are active partners of people smugglers. With the consistent policy of Matteo Salvini, Italy's Interior Minister, illegal immigration from Libya to the EU has fallen to a fraction of what it used to be, while drowning deaths have decreased. Did you hear what I just said? Drowning deaths have decreased.  But what is the German Government and the European political left doing? You want to accelerate the illegal immigration avalanche. We cannot solve africa's problems by bringing Africa's problems to Europe. Stop the political goodwill, it will sink Europe. (Applause)

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in the central Mediterranean is shameful.  Trafficking in human beings is constantly supported by unscrupulous NGOs which, in order to achieve their political plan, are ready to violate the laws and territorial waters of a sovereign state, which also coincide with the external borders of the European Union, as well as the laws of the sea themselves and which, on the contrary, use their defence hypocritically, as was the case with the outlaw Carola Rackete. , which ended its long series of violations by ramming a lookout of the Italian Guardia di Finanza, risking causing a tragedy. Some people would even like to give this outlaw a bridge in this Parliament.  All this in the complicit silence of the European authorities and with hypocritical statements by some governments, starting with those of France and Germany. So we at sea want fewer NGOs and more military vessels, because the only way to stop human trafficking and deaths at sea is to prevent the barges of death from leaving Africa and to open the identification centres there in which to distinguish who is really a refugee from those who are economic brigands and must be repatriated, and that is why we want a European mechanism for the return of migrants. , because only in this way will this irregular and immoral traffic be stopped.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: Madam President, we on the left – because I have heard humanitarian and Christian approaches to the issue – do not want refugees. What we want is to eliminate the causes of the refugee crisis and that is why you are not talking. What I'm asking today is that you identify these causes. The Commissioner yesterday spoke of greater military involvement with NATO, that is to say, she told us with insolence that she wants us to reinforce the causes of refugee flows. I don't know. To restore the European imperium? For more profitable international business?  The Mediterranean has become a graveyard of souls. In Greece, with a left-wing government, in the midst of the crisis, we fought a battle. Europe must do the same until peaceful reconstruction. That is what we are calling for; for Europe to be immediately disengaged from the outbreaks of conflict, military and economic; absolute support for solidarity organisations. The organization of solidarity is not an enemy, the enemy is war and your policies. The Mediterranean will only become truly safe when it is peaceful on both sides.  Ladies and gentlemen of the European Right, you have opened wounds, you have closed borders. That's your policy!

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Madam President, I am a newly elected Member from the Slovak Republic, but I must really say that I am appalled at how it actually works here. The European Union has not even started working properly in this parliamentary term, the European institutions are not even up and started, and the very first thing that is being dealt with here is how to help even more immigrants get to Europe. There are calls among MEPs for - at least what I have seen - to improve the protection of animals in transport, for the protection of elephants in Africa, but for the protection of Native Europeans, nothing, not a word. Let them just endure it all, let them just pay for it all. You are saying that immigrants in the Mediterranean must be helped because some people have drowned there. However, humanitarian aid in this case is not a solution at all; On the contrary, if we want to prevent drownings, the death of people in the Mediterranean, the only solution is to allow or help Member States at Europe's borders so that they can effectively defend their territory, so that they can crack down on smugglers and immigrant smugglers, so that they can cut off immigration routes, and then, if they do not accept any illegal immigrants, no illegal immigrants will even sail to Europe, and logically none will be in europe. This is the only way to end this unfortunate illegal immigration crisis. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. " I am also a new Member of Polish, I am a lawyer, I am lingua of maritime law. What my colleague just said is horrible and inhumane. Do you think that we Europeans are other, better people than refugees from Africa? Could we be rescued in the Mediterranean and refugees from needy countries not? Where are our European, fundamental, Christian values?

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam Colleague, I have not said a word about any better or worse people, no way. I am just saying that the European Union's current solutions to tackling illegal immigration are simply failing. This is also visible to us, to members who oppose immigration, to have a much greater presence in the European Parliament than before, so those old solutions simply do not work, and if we want to help the people of Africa, let us help them in Africa, let us leave them alone, or let us put some development aid there than the Union, but certainly immigration is not the solution, because the whole of Africa will not fit into Europe.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This summer's events with the rescue ship in Italy show that Europe still lacks a long-term and sustainable migration policy. Let us be very clear, however, that the answers do not come from the extreme left or from the right-wing populists. However, there are lessons to be learned from these events. Firstly, laws and regulations must apply. Operations in the Mediterranean save lives, but they must take place within the law and in cooperation with the Member States. Secondly, the action of the Italian Government does not solve the basic problem. Instead, it is rather to shift responsibility to other countries. Thirdly, make sure that we move towards a policy of rapid asylum searches, so that we can also develop a sustainable migration policy in the future.

name: Pietro BARTOLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with emotion and respect, I am addressing this House for the first time. I am lampedusan – perhaps some people do not know – and for thirty years in Lampedusa, europe's gateway, I personally rescued, personally welcomed, and personally cared for those who arrive after a long journey at sea. I have seen pure horror, I have done thousands of cadaver inspections, I have seen hormonal torture, I have seen the disease of the dinghy – someone here does not know what it is talking about – I have seen so many horrors, which I do not want to describe here. Europe cannot abandon men, women and children at sea and send them back to the hell of Libya. We have a responsibility to these people. That is why I urgently call for a new European plan for search and rescue in the Mediterranean.  In recent years, NGOs active in the Mediterranean have saved thousands of lives, make up for the shortcomings of governments, closed in on their national self-interest and unable to find solutions in the name of solidarity. Yet many have pointed the finger at these organisations, criminalising them for offering humanitarian aid and for respecting the law of the sea. This must not happen again.  I call for the aiding directive to be amended: those who offer humanitarian aid cannot and must not be criminalised. And if we really want to prevent thousands of people from making dangerous journeys to Europe every day, we need legal channels not only for asylum seekers, but also for those fleeing poverty, hunger and adverse weather conditions.  Last March, this Parliament voted on an ambitious resolution on humanitarian visas, asking the Commission to present a legislative proposal. Well, the new Commission will promote it and show a strong political commitment also to completing the Dublin reform that this Parliament has already voted for by a large majority.  The Member States assume their responsibility in Helsinki, they discuss, not ad hoc measures, but long-term policies.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, if I were a person threatened with drowning in the Mediterranean, the words of some of our colleagues who do not care about the misfortune of these people, I would spit on it. Humanitarian action must not be neutral but impartial. It must not be neutral, in the sense of equidistance between the victims and their tormentors, because it must always side with the weak and the persons in danger. It must be impartial because humanitarian action does not distinguish between victims, regardless of their origin, nationality or opinion. Exposure to danger, pursuit or war alone is sufficient to deploy it. The principles thus defined, notably by Henry Dunant, have been codified in the meantime.
