They are now the norms of international humanitarian law and, consequently, maritime law. Is Mr Salvini solely responsible for the appalling situation in the Mediterranean? No. Those who refuse to take in people saved in the Mediterranean are equally responsible as he is. There are therefore no mitigating circumstances to justify refusing to help those in danger. Indifference, in this circumstance, is not an opinion, it is a crime. Therefore, I think it is wise to ask some of our Member States, which have nothing to do with humanitarian law and the principles that underlie it, to return to compliance with standards. Finally, I call on the future Commission to continue to assign this portfolio to a Commissioner who will have no other function than that of Commissioner for Humanitarian Action. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Claire FOX
text: blue-card question. – I want to ask you whether you think that, by saying that anybody who has qualms about an open humanitarian process is guilty of a crime, is not letting the EU off the hook. The EU created Fortress Europe. The EU is ultimately responsible for those drowning in the Mediterranean. It is an absolute nerve to have a go at nation-states who dare do what? Assert their national sovereignty to make decisions about who they welcome. It’s the EU with blood on its hands or rather those drowned people. Don’t try and play the humanitarian card in order to guilt-trip people in this room for simply saying that nation-states should be able to decide who they have live in their countries, and don’t say that you are more humanitarian than others because you hang your heart on your sleeve in this House.  (Applause)

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Answer "blue card." Madam President, I would like to say to the person who has just questioned me that if I have a choice between a misunderstood sovereignty of a Member State and the duty to protect human beings, the choice is not difficult to make. What I would like to add to my point is that there are states in our European Union that behave as if they have never heard of law, a community of values and respect for humanitarian law. It is imperative, and I repeat my introductory remarks, those who do not respect these principles, I will spit on it.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We Greens cannot silently watch as thousands of people's lives are lost. We, the EUROPEAN Union, do not save lives by making fine statements about stopping people smuggling or by agreements with rogue states such as Libya. People are dying at this moment. I would therefore like to call on the newly elected President, Mrs von der Leyen, and the Council to take two decisive decisions immediately.  Firstly, stop Member States criminalising civilian aid operations in the Mediterranean. Saving lives can never be a crime! Instead, demand that these Member States make every effort to save lives with the help of all of us. Secondly, take a joint decision on a long-term solution based on solidarity both with the people fleeing and with the Member States that are taking the heaviest advantage.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, this year 682 people have died trying to enter Europe via the Mediterranean. It is a tragic assessment that should prompt us to think about the best way to prevent such tragedies from happening again. In my opinion, the solution is not to open our ports to migrant boats chartered by smugglers, nor is it to create legal channels of immigration because, in both cases, it would produce a call for air that would encourage more and more migrants to attempt the mediterranean crossing, at the risk of their lives. The real solution is the one indicated by Italy, it is to systematically turn back migrant boats and punish their captains when they behave like smugglers. It also means exchanging our aid to African countries for their commitment to really combat the immigration of their nationals. It is only by adopting this policy of firmness that Europe will be able to protect itself and save lives.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The European Union must be one step ahead of smugglers. This type of migration policy must not be cultivated under the influence of emotions and must be long-term, coherent and consistent, and the basis of this policy should be prudence. So let's focus on actions at source. From the discussions I had as Polish Minister for Humanitarian Aid directly with refugees, it was clear that organised crime groups, for a fee of between one thousand and one thousand five hundred euros (or dollars), offer transport to Europe and inform about further procedures for drawing families. There is one cure for this: to absolutely increase development aid in African countries and to implement a broad information campaign on our return and asylum policy. And it is necessary to examine carefully what are the real intentions of the captains of ships receiving from the sea and helping to transfer migrants from Africa to Europe. Can we still talk about sar action or about criminalising aid to illegal immigrants? This is a great task for the authorities involved in the fight against international crime. This problem must not be different to us, but must be the basis for a common long-term strategy against illegal immigration. People need to be rescued, that's right, but someone sends them to certain death. Let us not be naïve.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, strip away the nice words and the reality is that Europe’s asylum and migration system is built around the desires of the arms industry, who profit twice. Firstly, from the wars that make people refugees in the first place and then reaping the rewards of multi-billion euro border-security contracts to keep the victims away from us. Now what sort of a choice is it? That you’re so desperate that you leave your family, your friends, everything you know and you’ve either got to gamble with your life on the Mediterranean – depending on the valiant efforts of NGOs – or you find yourself in a detention camp in Libya to be raped, starved, exploited and tortured. And do you know what? There seems to be no end to Europe’s attitude to keep Fortress Europe alive. The Commission’s contemptuous dismissal of the call by the UN to end the migrant returns to Italy after the air strike really tells us all we need to know. The utter failure to overturn and reform the Dublin Regulation also tells it. It’s a blight on all of our consciences.

name: Louis STEDMAN-BRYCE
text: – Madam President, I have to say it’s been a long time since I’ve had so much rubbish and hypocrisy as I’ve heard in here this afternoon. Yesterday we heard the new Commission President talk about gender diversity; not once did she mention about ethnic diversity, which I think is quite a hypocrisy there. If we want to see diversity in the European institutions then the best way to do that is to wait for the cleaning staff that leave here in the mornings and watch the faces of the white MEPs that come in as they are leaving.  We’ve got scaremongers who would have us believe that the UK would turn into a racist society when we leave this institution and believe me, we will be leaving, but we will continue to lead this fight and be one of the most ethnically diverse countries represented in this Parliament. So basically that’s all I have to say on this. Hypocrisy all the way. Disgusting.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr Stedman-Bryce, I feel obliged to make a remark about your choice of words. Members are not supposed to use offensive language, so when you talk about ‘rubbish’, please be careful.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support There's no question that people in trouble need help. The question is how and where. The problem should be treated at the root. Time has shown that radically fewer migrants are lost in the Mediterranean since tighter border protection there. Mass deaths are caused by Europe letting people smugglers and NGO vessels from unexplained backgrounds operate undisturbed at sea. The right thing to do, humanitarian aid, is to make it clear that illegal border crossing is not a viable option. The responsibility of the new European Parliament is also enormous.  Let us also make it clear to the European Parliament and the EU leadership that the European Union's external, land and sea borders must be protected. THE OPERATION OF NGO vessels assisting in the smuggling of human beings should be prevented. We need to distinguish economic migrants from real refugees and bring help where there is trouble, not bring trouble here. Border protection not only protects Europe, but also saves lives. If we finally make it clear that there is no point in leaving Africa in soul-losing boats, then no one will be lost in the sea. This new leadership has been given the opportunity to finally act, soberly, truly philanthropically, to save lives and at the same time protect the lives of the people of Europe.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, yesterday, the future President of the Commission undertook to open a new phase in the common migration policy. We can't wait. Let's move from words to deeds. The Mediterranean has become a cemetery. We have to close it. 18,000 deaths between 2014 and 2018. Not one more death! For us, immigrants are not figures: they are people fleeing war, persecution or poverty, and every death is a tragedy. We cannot stand by the words of revulsion every time a ship sinks off our coast, nor in the one-off solidarity solutions offered by some progressive governments—read the Pedro Sanchez government—when mafias leave thousands of migrants adrift. We cannot let immigrants be the victims of conflicts between traffickers, NGOs dedicated to rescuing immigrants and irresponsible governments, read the Italian Government, who punish the duty to save lives at sea and evade respect for the union's values. We cannot wait in each case to know how the soap pool ends: whether ports and borders will remain closed; whether the captains will be imprisoned; if emergency ships will arrive in time to save lives. I therefore call for the new Community Executive and the Member States to undertake to urgently present an emergency plan from the European Union, with a legal framework and adequate financial instruments and resources, for the landing and relocation of rescued migrants in the Mediterranean. We must move into action with will, political responsibility, determination, prioritizing the humanitarian approach, solidarity between member states.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, according to the International Organization for Migration, this year alone 682 people have died or gone missing in the Mediterranean. Another shocking figure is that, over the last five years, 250 people were prosecuted because they tried to help refugees. The figure I have not found is how many human smugglers we have put on trial. So I think we have the wrong focus. We should not put volunteers on trial. We have to put the focus on the smugglers. So I was very glad when Ms Ursula von der Leyen said that we have a moral duty to save lives at sea. That’s the Europe I want to stand for. So let us not accept a Europe where women, children and men drown at sea. Let us work together to make a real migration policy in Europe and save the people at sea.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as soon as President Sassoli was elected, he said that parliament's doors are open to NGOs transporting illegal immigrants to Italy.  In the Mediterranean, NGOs do not save lives, but are accomplices of human traffickers. Carola Rackete is not a hero, but she is a German citizen who has violated Italian laws and rammed a ship of the Guardia di Finanza. Anywhere else in the world would be in jail. The Italians are tired of this Europe, a friend of illegal immigrants. On 26 May, 9 million Italians voted for the change, carried out by the League of Matteo Salvini. They voted no to the invasion of illegal immigrants, they voted to say yes to the defence of borders. We will continue with the policy of zero tolerance and expulsions, whether the new European Commission likes it or not. Sassoli and his Catholic communist friends take the illegal immigrants home to their homes and villas and stop morality to Italian citizens who only demand justice, security and respect for the law.

name: Raffaele STANCANELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, having only one minute to express my opinion on a subject of extreme complexity, I would like to quote a great European patriot, Pope John Paul II.  In his apostolic exhortation "Ecclesia in Europa" published in 2003, the Polish Pope wrote: "it is the responsibility of public authorities to exercise control of migratory flows in consideration of the needs of the common good. Reception must always take place in compliance with the law and therefore be combined, when necessary, with the firm repression of abuses."  I would like to remind members of this House that, instead of supporting the actions of those who do not respect the laws of a Member State, we should all do even more to create the economic and social conditions so that anyone can stay in their own country, instead of trying to make a fortune elsewhere.  Finally, let me stress the generosity of the Sicilians and Italians, who in recent years have continued to save lives at sea and welcome those in need, but who have also asked us loudly, through the vote in May, to assume our responsibilities.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, how many thousands of deaths and how many court decisions will it take for Member States and the European Commission to set up a genuine European search and rescue operation in the Mediterranean? And not like Sofia, which I repeat as a naval operation but which is maintained for a few months without boats, which must probably, I repeat, be European humor. Let's take it backwards. The main argument we've heard today against this type of operation is that it would promote the call for air. What we need to understand is that saving those who are ready to die in order to arrive in Europe and welcome them with dignity will bring even more people. But, sincerely, is there no one left to risk his life in the Mediterranean since rescues in the Mediterranean are criminalized or absent? The answer is no, and there are just - so to speak - more deaths in 2018, 2,275 or one person for 51 crossings. Only a powerful European mission dedicated to search and rescue at sea will save lives, but also save the honour of the European Union. And as long as I am talking about honour, it is also the dignity of the Union to enforce the law on decent landings and reception. Let's end it on a case-by-case basis and short-term solutions.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, we are talking about humanitarian assistance and we are talking about humanitarian law. So when Italian ports closed access to NGOs saving immigrants today, they were violating international humanitarian law and international maritime law. During this year, more than 1,100 people have died in the Mediterranean and another 10,000 have been intercepted and forced back to Libya. To Libya, to refugee camps that do not have the slightest conditions and which, as happened on 14 July, are bombed, such as the Tayura camp, where more than sixty migrants died. The United Nations has called on the European Union to evacuate these immigrant camps. And not only have we not, but we continue to force intercepted immigrants to return to Libya. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not deceive ourselves: the disappearance or disposal of ships in the Mediterranean, the detention of their captains, do not reduce the number of migrants; they just reduce their chances of saving their lives. Let us not deceive ourselves: to fight against the mafias we must legislate; the Council's migration package must be unlocked; safe routes must be established; humanitarian visas must be established, and Member States have to comply jointly and severally with the obligations of reception, sharing and resettlement. As long as legal paralysis, the Council's ability to paralyze the asylum and shelter package continues, we will unfortunately continue to stack bodies in the Mediterranean.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleague, I must remind you that if you have one minute you can’t speak for one minute 45 seconds, because someone else will lose the speaking time.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as a League, as an Italian people we will never stop, we will never tire of saying stop illegal immigration, of saying no to the business of trafficking in human beings, and a healthy European institution should listen to constructive criticism from Italy, one of the six founding countries of this Europe. Instead, this Europe, a Europe sick of economic speculation, continues to make bad choices and fuels confrontation, feeds the dead. We want a Europe that knows how to cure, that heals the problems of this Europe and that does not feed the epidemic of these problems with crazy policies of reception for immigration and Islamic recruitment.  We will continue to fight, we will never be your accomplices in the criminal project of impoverishment of peoples.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, for 5 years in this Chamber we have been having this conversation with you, right in this chamber for 5 years we have been listening to the same emptyness, general talk, overflowing from empty to empty, in general politics in this area is a complete failure, dear Commissioner. And now I turn to you, dear fellow communists, socialists, greens, pinks, the colleague in the yellow hat who may have left the chamber, etc. – until yesterday you wanted the rule of law, you wanted to punish Poland, Hungary, because they were against the rule of law. Today you want to break the law. Where's the truth here, dear? When are you honest with your constituents? Either you want to respect international law and the law or you don't want to. When you support traffickers, you violate international law and the law. There is no difference between the traffickers you support and somali pirates, for example, think about it. There will be no casualties in the Mediterranean if you do not support human traffickers. There will be no casualties if your MPs do not board illegal ships and violate the sovereign borders of countries such as Italy, Spain, Bulgaria and Greece. Countries have borders that need to be respected, migration must be zero. And since I heard a provocation a while ago, I will tell you colleagues, it is useful to read "History of Europe". Europe is a Christian civilization, it has its Christian roots and Christian values, and when you are visiting it is brought up to do as the host.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The civil war in Libya has added to the devastating situation of the refugees in the torture camps there. In a recent case, gun-wielders forced people fleeing the next missile strike to stay in the camp. Shortly thereafter, a rocket hit, killing 53 refugees. In the light of these events, what else must happen for the European Commission to fundamentally review and also consider abandoning cooperation with the Libyan coastguard and finally to evacuate the refugees in the Libyan camps? The IOM and the United Nations are calling for the latter. How clear is it that those rescued from distress at sea cannot be returned to Libya? Instead of continuing to provide militias with EU money, I call for an immediate European civil sea rescue programme. In order to do this, we must ensure that European ports are finally reopened. That is what international law provides for.  Italy's far-right interior minister has been waging a defamation campaign against the rescue organisation Sea-Watch for weeks. His intention is to portray existing law as an injustice. But our solidarity is due to Carola Rackete and all other maritime rescue organisations. Action must finally be taken now! People fleeing wars and political persecution, hardship and misery must be treated fairly and on the basis of human rights. (Loud protests from the right side of the house)

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, anyone with compassion would be deeply moved by the situation in the Mediterranean. People are in danger and we have the power in our hands to save lives. But also our English Channel is becoming a dangerous crossing point for refugees. Last month 43 people in small boats landed on South—East England’s coasts. Traffickers are locked up every week in our courts. I prosecuted many of them, and Brexit will make things much worse. It will kill the cooperation we need to save refugees’ lives, to arrest human traffickers and to repair the failed states that create refugees. Europe must use its power to rebuild good government in failed states. Europe can rise to this challenge. People want to stop Brexit so Britain can be part of this important work.

name: Gianna GANCIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course, these debates also demonstrate this, the European Union has shown itself incapable of adopting a coherent and shared approach to the migration crisis, a structural phenomenon that is the result of the economic and social contexts of sub-Saharan Africa.  There's a paradox. The paradox is that, faced with a structural problem – I repeat – which is in danger of becoming a global humanitarian disaster, the European Union continues to operate under a state of emergency. Let us remember the progress of global warming and the population growth of the African continent, which will explode in a few years' time.  Instead of doing as it has done so far, the European Union must adopt a forward-looking political vision that moves in two directions. Firstly, the European institutions must, with all legislative and political pressure, activate a comprehensive reform of the Dublin III Regulation as soon as possible, while respecting the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.  Secondly, the European Union must stand as guarantor of the geopolitical stability of North Africa and at the same time contribute to the pursuit of sustainable and just development in the countries of origin.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, everyone. As the first time I have chaired the plenary of the European Parliament, I would like to say that it is an honour to have been elected your second Vice-President and that I thank you for your confidence. I will work with everyone to strengthen the European Parliament and European democracy.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, saving lives is a moral imperative, not just a legal obligation.  According to Unicef data, already in the first three months of 2019 there were about 16 000 migrants and refugees who reached Europe through mediterranean migration routes, and although this figure shows a decrease compared to the same period of 2018, the percentage of children and adolescents in the total arrivals has increased from 20 to 25 %.  That is why, in departing from the previous speakers, I would like to draw attention to the need to guarantee maximum protection for the most vulnerable migrants: children and adolescents; in particular, unaccompanied children and adolescents, who are most at risk of abuse, violence and exploitation by unscrupulous traffickers.  With the Intergroup on the Rights of the Child, which I had the honour of chairing during the last parliamentary term, we have repeatedly stressed that all children must receive protection and assistance, and in particular those who have experienced tragic situations, such as small migrants arriving on our shores. And the countries of first arrival, such as Italy, my country, cannot be left alone. The migration crisis must be managed at European level.  The amendment of the Dublin Regulation, the establishment of legal and safe immigration channels, the fight against human traffickers are just some of the essential measures to combine legality and solidarity, and to ensure the protection of children's rights, as laid down in the UN Convention, whose 30th anniversary will be celebrated on 20 November, is the responsibility of all the countries of the Union. Because children's rights do not and must not have borders.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, the defence of the rule of law is a priority of the Finnish Presidency. A good issue to demonstrate this is to put in place the many States and governments that are failing to comply with international asylum and maritime legislation in the face of the tragedy of the Mediterranean. They hinder rescues, block initiatives like that of Aita Mari, a tunaman turned rescue ship; an initiative that has united Basque and Andalusian citizens; demonstrating that European citizenship is solidarity; which advises that local and regional institutions, which they actually welcome and serve, can bring that experience to those who turn people into numbers, who are treated by rescuers as criminals. I hope that this breath of fresh air, which proposals such as the Basque Share will reach the Council tables. It is hopeful that Ursula von der Leyen, who ousted a Syrian refugee at home, will bear witness, as President of the Commission, to values that should unite us all.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened carefully to the speeches of the Council and the Commission and many of my fellow Members, and I will not hide from you my deep misgivings about observing so much hypocrisy in the proper framework of the problem.  Our common Christian roots require a deep focus on human rights, but we cannot allow the feeling of solidarity to become an alibi, an alibi for increasing illicit and criminal trafficking that exploits migratory flows. If opening ports means fuelling deportations and deluding thousands of migrants in Europe who are waiting for them in paradise, while they are going to enrich the mafias, then we cannot be complicit. Europol has pointed out that this new slave trade is worth six billion a year and is one of the most profitable criminal industries. Each new slave pays four, five thousand euros to earn a place under the bridges or perhaps an exploitation of two euros an hour.  The whole of Europe should stand shoulder to shoulder with our government in respect of national laws and not make the usual good-natured cheer and give medal to the Carola Rackete on duty who, arrogantly, rams a lookout of our Guardia di Finanza. It should be understood that the pressure to the south of the continent will soon affect all borders. It is a question of common sense, Mr President, simple common sense.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to return to the heart of the debate, so I ask you all: would you flee from home just because you might be saved if you are in distress at sea? Certainly not! This far-reaching decision is made when you are under political or personal pressure at home, because you lose everything you love – your family, your friends, familiarity, language, culture. So the pull argument doesn't pull, and it's actually quite simple: can it be criminal to save lives? No. Letting thousands of people die in the Mediterranean has nothing to do with reason or reality. The debate on this alone shows the devastating image of human beings that has now taken root in Europe. It's for genetic engineering. And to whom all this is not enough; of course, sea rescue is also a manifold, multiple legal obligation. This Parliament has been calling for years for a reform of Dublin towards a common, solidarity-based and humane asylum system. However, the blockade of individual Member States in the Council has prevented precisely such a solution for years. Instead, we are making political capital out of it, and that is precisely what is dangerous. It divides Europe and it promotes the rejection of the EU because it is unable to offer solutions. This House has a clear decision-making position. Let us increase the pressure on the Council with our common strength. Effective proposals are on the table, let us turn them into reality!

name: Valter FLEGO
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, respected colleagues, the Mediterranean Sea in recent years has become one of the places of greatest danger to people, not only in Europe, unfortunately and beyond.  In 2017 and 2018, about 8,000 people lost on that sea, a sea that was supposed to be a sea of hope, and it became a sea of death, its own life. That means we failed. We all failed together. Member States of Europe, the Commission, society, we have failed and therefore we need much greater coordination, determination, much greater cooperation between the Member State and the Commission and a clear strategy and action and shared responsibility.  It cannot be for migrants that only the state where they want to come can be responsible, and that is why I call on the European Commission to act quickly and jointly to find a fair and humane solution, taking into account the safety of its citizens, but solutions that do not justify the "use of a little force", as expressed by the President of the Republic of Croatia. I condemn such a statement because the Croatia I represent stands for humanity and for the protection of the dignity of every human being.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, saving lives is not, it cannot be a crime. We cannot criminalise those who only comply with the basic principles of human rights and the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.  It is short-sighted to imagine that refugees and immigrants will no longer seek an opportunity to live safely and with dignity if there is no one to help them. It is therefore important to review the Immigration Facilitation Directive, to review the Dublin rules, to develop a common asylum policy, based on the joint sharing of the responsibility of international protection, and an integrated immigration policy should also be developed, based on legal and secure channels and a development cooperation policy capable of responding to the causes of emigration.  To deny humanitarian aid, to deny dignified treatment to any human being, to deny the inalienable right to life is to deny the humanistic identity of Europe and to commit a crime against humanity.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, at the outset I just want to say that the European Union has an obligation to do an awful lot more than it is presently doing. We cannot have a situation where the burden falls on a few states to deal with the particular humanitarian crisis that is unfolding in the Mediterranean. So there’s a moral imperative on us to ensure that we have sensible immigration policies but, in the meantime, the people who are clinging to boats in the Mediterranean cannot be allowed to wait. We have to ensure that we have a new search and rescue mission immediately in the Mediterranean.  The Irish navy was previously involved in Operation Sophia, where it rescued thousands of people. I now call on the Commission, along with the Member States which have naval support, to ensure that we have a proper search and rescue mission put in place immediately to address the unfolding humanitarian crisis.  The long-term issue of immigration can be addressed as well but we have this moral imperative immediately. I have been disappointed that the Irish Government has not funded the Irish navy to the point where we now have two naval ships tied up in dry dock because of a lack of personnel. They should be in the Mediterranean Sea, along with other naval boats from other countries, addressing this humanitarian crisis. Urgently act.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Ladies and gentlemen, let us now start the period of the so-called "catch the eye", I am happy to inform you that I hope to have the floor to all those who have signed up as long as they strictly comply with the time of 1 minute.  Interventions "catch the eye"

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Mr President, the European Union is a community of values, but it is also a community of law. That is why it is difficult to accept a debate in which a dilemma seems to arise: either lives are saved or the law is enforced. It's a false dilemma we can't accept. There is an Anglo-Saxon principle that says "Hard cases make bad law". I believe that, in this debate, we want to make good law or establish good policies through unique cases. Human trafficking is a cruel and brutal reality in Europe: sea traffic and land traffic. But it is clear that victims cannot be confused with their perpetrators. At the beginning of the Finnish Presidency, when there is a new presidency in the Commission, I would invite you again to go to southern Spain, to Tarifa, to realize that a few miles away is Africa and to know that there will have to be a much more ambitious and structured policy of cooperation to work in and with the countries that originate from immigration. And only the European Union can do this.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, we are once again discussing the lives of thousands of men, women and children who every day attempt the perilous journey across the Mediterranean, fleeing conflict and unsustainable lives. Many have died, but many have also been saved increasingly by humanitarian NGOs such as Open Arms, a Spanish initiative which is now working across the wider Mediterranean.  I’d like to speak about Carola Rackete, the Captain of Sea-Watch 3, arrested last month for docking the search and rescue vessel in Italy without permission, but trying to save hundreds of lives. This woman is not a criminal, as Salvini would have you believe. She is a heroine, and I salute her. I also salute the Spanish fireman Miguel Roldán who took leave from his job to join the Iuventa German rescue boat and helped to save 5 000 people. He faces a possible jail sentence of 20 years for being braver, compassionate and far more principled than most people in this House. And I’m proud that my Group, the Socialists and Democrats, nominated humanitarian NGOs for the Sakharov Prize. They would have been worthy winners.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Stylianides, Mr Styliani. They pretend that the distress of the sea has fallen from the sky. It is not. In the 1960s, 70s, 80s and 90s there was no mass distress at sea in the Mediterranean. This distress at sea has not fallen from the sky, it has been deliberately brought about by smugglers. And what are your answers? They are always the same non-functioning answers. The first answer is to throw and give even more money to corrupt regimes in Africa. That doesn't work. The second answer is to create jobs in Africa. Mr Stylianides, you are not even able to do that in Cyprus. Youth unemployment in Cyprus is now where, at 16, at 17%? It is a scandal. And the third answer, of course, is quotas – to distribute refugees with quotas. All these proposals are not working and they have not worked for years. The peoples of Europe do not want them. They want jobs here, and they do not want more and more people who come here to live at their expense and trample on the very values that we claim to defend in the Mediterranean. That is not what the people of Europe want.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, listening to the bench on the left, I wanted to know whether we really want to put in a kind of hotline to bring in anyone who wants to somehow come, and to automatically grant the right to come to Europe to the 1.3 billion Africans, who are going to be 2.5 billion Africans in twenty-five years. What we're really talking about is nonsense. We are trying to solve a crisis on a continent by simply primating a number of traffickers and taking precedence over groups that, for ideological reasons, are working with these traffickers, in a performance that is the one that has triggered the risk there, because it brings many young people; many of the best, most dynamic, most imaginative young people within these countries, he takes them out of there, encourages them to do that emigration — to spend money, to set out on a suicide adventure — precisely because of that call that NGOs nurtur, generating the business of traffickers. Let's see if we can find out.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Mr President, thank you for allowing me to catch your eye. It seems to me that this is one of the most complex and challenging issues that the EU faces currently, and there is no right answer for it. At the moment it seems that there is a clash between what Europe wants and what individual nations need. Only by the new policy addressing all of these things will we be able to resolve it. We absolutely have to do more in Africa, but we have to make sure we reward the right people, not the wrong people. The second thing is we must absolutely have strong borders but, when people arrive in Europe, what we see is chaos. And so we must make sure that our own systems of processing migrants, returning those who need to go back, go back, but those who are allowed to stay can stay. In doing that, we must absolutely support the national countries who are having to face that – and I think of places like Italy and Greece and the local communities who are really struggling to deal with it on behalf of the rich countries. The third thing, or the final thing that we must do is we must make ‘if you want to do it, all the nations will have to pay’. It won’t be the UK, because we’re leaving, but it is going to be very, very expensive and you will all have to pay.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I believe that Ursula von der Leyen will deliver on the promises she has made: promises to save lives at sea. And I urge us to strive not to close the European maritime rescue system to anyone. Every life is worth the same. What is different is saving lives, and what is different is asylum policy and relocation, as well as the further situation of those rescued. These two orders must not be confused, because this is immoral. I would very much like all of us to show solidarity in this European area. We cannot leave only some countries with this burden. I am sorry, because Poland, my country, unfortunately does not get involved in these matters.  Nor can we accuse those who save lives. We cannot criminalise the rescuers and we must establish a system of assistance for those who are fleeing and fleeing because this escape across the sea is the only rescue.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on his efforts to distribute humanitarian aid effectively, with the primary concern being to save and protect lives. However, I cannot hide my disappointment because as a European Union as a whole we have failed to address the causes. But while the flow of refugees reaches the European shores of the Mediterranean, our culture dictates that saving lives is not a crime, it is our moral obligation. But when Turkey deliberately diverts hundreds of refugees to the occupied northern part of Cyprus, which is occupied by the Turkish army, to then cross into the free areas and reach Europe, this is indeed a crime, which the Cypriot government is constantly denouncing.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Mr President, six years ago, Australia faced the same situation as Europe, with a massive influx of illegal immigrants. The response chosen by the Australian Prime Minister at the time, Tony Abbott, was very clear: zero tolerance, no way. The results were also rapid, the deaths at sea ceased and, quickly, the message was understood. Illegal immigration has ceased in Australia. Today, I think that this is the same policy that we need to adopt in Europe and I consider that with the laws and the political message sent by Matteo Salvini, it is a much more effective way of saving lives, rather than getting a certain number of people to go to sea, even to save them. And what I expect from the European institutions today is above all that they have a real European policy which consists first of all in not distributing illegal immigrants, but in ensuring that they do not arrive on European territory, by ensuring that, like Australia, refugee applications are processed, for example, in other countries bordering the European Union. We know very well that in Europe we enter illegally and that in this way we keep it. So let's prevent illegal entry and then we'll really have a solution.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to address this chamber for the first time on such an important and sensitive subject. Sometimes, when I hear some colleagues in this house talk about this humanitarian issue, I wonder if our difference is only political or if it is also a difference in sensitivity, it is a difference in degree of empathy towards these kinds of people who put their lives at risk by fleeing persecution, wars and misery. That said, it's true that we can do more. Parliament approved its position on the reform of the Dublin Regulation, and we also hope and continue to expect the Council to do its job instead.  The Commission could also have done more. Commissioner Stylianides, we have asked you many times to change the Aid Directive which, as you know, is used by some Member States to criminalise non-governmental organisations. Please, there is still time to correct this situation.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, NGOs are criminalising themselves. It is news a few minutes ago that the PM Patronage of Agrigento asked for the imprisonment of Carola Rackete for an unjustified act of force. A judge says so, a politician does not say it, whether he likes it or not, he is a judge of a sovereign state, which has laws and these laws must be respected by everyone.  No one wants deaths at sea, but we cannot leave the management of such an important phenomenon to private organisations, of which we may know little. We must put an end to the hypocrisy of this state, of this European Union, and focus on stabilising the places from which these people come – I am thinking of Libya – and this is not done perhaps by selling weapons under the counter to one dictator or another, but it is done by stabilising these territories and consolidating the humanitarian corridors only for those who really need assistance. , and only those who are truly political refugees.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Mr President, I am certainly perplexed — and that is why I have asked for the floor — with some of the things I have been hearing during this debate. I listened here until Captain Carola had attacked an Italian Navy ship, which she was more powerful than a captain of a humanitarian ship, but, well, anyway. I know this is a difficult problem; I believe that from this we are all aware, that it is not arranged only with goodwill, evidently. But what I'm sure of is that it's not fixed with ill will. It doesn't fix the lack of guts. It's not fixed with a lack of empathy. Here it has been raised, and it is also raised in my country by the far right - we have seen here one of its representatives - a terrible syllogism to deal with this situation, which is that, if we stop allowing humanitarian aid in the Mediterranean, the example will stop immigrants coming via the Mediterranean, which gives us a terrible conclusion, that is, , the exemplary are the dead. If we stop caring for those who can drown in the Mediterranean, when there are no known how many dead, Ladies and Gentlemen, will stop coming. And that is absolutely unacceptable according to our own principles. Don't you want NGO ships helping immigrants? Well, ladies and gentlemen, Community policy, common policy of the European Union, public media, reform of the Dublin Regulation. That's the only way. They call us hypocrites, but hypocrites are you, because they don't care about anything that loses their lives in the Mediterranean.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you, dear colleagues, for this very important debate. The Commission considers that humanitarian imperatives have been, and shall continue to be, at the forefront of European Union action. As I said in my opening remarks, the Commission has repeatedly recalled that the EU and its Member States are bound by the duty to render assistance to persons or vessels in distress at sea, and it is an obligation under international law. It is a moral duty. International law is binding on states which are obliged to subject the captains of private, commercial or military vessels to the corresponding duty to render assistance. Saving lives at sea must therefore go hand in hand with addressing the main causes of irregular migration and improving the situation of migrants in Libya and other countries in offering safe alternatives such as resettlement for those entitled to international protection or legal labour migration schemes for those who qualify. I wish also to renew once again my appeal to all Member States to make their contribution to speeding up evacuation of vulnerable migrants and refugees from Libya and Niger. I thank you for your support in building a comprehensive EU response – a holistic EU response – and as I said, the Commission stands ready to continue to provide all the political, technical and financial support that Member States need to address the situation in the Mediterranean, and in particular to reach an agreement on temporary arrangements. The four years since the adoption of the European Agenda on Migration have shown that the situation requires continuous determined action across the full range of the comprehensive approach. The lesson is that united action and joint efforts from Member States and the EU, in close cooperation with partners beyond the EU, has delivered results and is the only way to achieve better management of migration and to ensure that the European Union’s values remain the cornerstone of our migration policy. This is what EU citizens expect from the European Union, from the European institutions. Again, I will quote the President-elect from yesterday: we need solidarity. We all need to help each other and contribute. We need a new way of burden-sharing. And we must make fair cooperation offers to countries of origin and transit which are in the interest of both sides. These are our priorities and we have to start immediately.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the Presidency is fully aware of the critical importance of providing humanitarian assistance in the Mediterranean Sea and we are committed to working on a solution in collaboration with all stakeholders.  I am grateful for your comments made during this discussion. I listened to them very carefully and I wish to react to them accordingly. As I said previously, we are working to find an arrangement, humane in nature, that brings predictability in accordance with the International Law of the Sea, concerning disembarkation and enables efficient asylum and return policies.  Our Presidency will continue active work on temporary arrangements. Actually the informal meeting of Ministers of the Interior will take place tomorrow in Helsinki and the situation in the Mediterranean will be discussed there. Furthermore, our Minister of the Interior has also invited all her Member State colleagues to an informal dinner no later than today to discuss the immediate situation in the Mediterranean.  It is clear that we need European solutions here. Close and intensive cooperation between institutions and common understanding among the Member States are key for the future migration policy. It is also very important that the new Commission also aims high here. As the new Commission President said yesterday in this very Chamber, we have a common responsibility to save lives at sea. Every life matters. Every life is equally important. It is of the utmost importance that we succeed quickly even if only with a temporary solution. However, we need one that covers all aspects. The EU as a whole, not to mention the migrants themselves, do not deserve that this situation stays unresolved.  At the same time, we will continue working on the reform of the Common European Asylum System to provide a permanent and humane solution to situations, such as the ones mentioned, in the future. I remain confident that, thanks to all our efforts, we can take an important step forward towards this goal. Thank you very much again for your contributions and for your attention.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Our debate is closed with this speech. Before we get to the next point on the agenda, we will take a brief five-minute break for consideration of the Commissioner and the Representative of the Council who have been with us for a long time.  Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that we are starting the work of the new EP with a debate on the humanitarian situation in the Mediterranean. The migration crisis in recent years has shown that we need to develop a system so that migrants who reach EU shores find help and shelter instead of sinking before our eyes. It is our duty to save lives. Is this not why we have enroled in our Treaties and Conventions of the European Community the need to protect human life?!  During the debate, much was said about the criminalisation of NGOs rescuing people from sinking boats. The efforts of the Italian Government, coastguard, Frontex and NATO are not enough to deal with the huge number of people trying to reach Europe. I hope that in the coming months a long-term, coherent migration management policy will be developed, which will be based on a humane approach and not on the particular interests of the Member States. We must create decent conditions for those migrants who have already arrived.  So that the Mediterranean is not a graveyard, let us create humane conditions (access to water, food, medicines) and development opportunities in the countries from which these people are fleeing. Instead of putting up walls, let us consider what to do so that migrants want and can stay in their places of origin. This is the only way to reduce the number of immigrants that may be more in the future. This is the most important issue in this parliamentary term.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The critique of so-called humanitarian assistance in the flows of illegal immigration across the Mediterranean has been made suspect because it is being used by populist governments and movements to justify their hard, anti-immigration stance. But the critique remains valid and needs a response. Sea projects originating and financed from outside the Mediterranean are serving to encourage people traffickers and migrants who would not otherwise attempt very dangerous crossings to multiply their activities. These ‘humanitarian’ entrepreneurs are subject to no proper regulation and basically engage in a catch-as-catch-can game with approaching migrant boats. The situation is not sustainable for political, security, economic and social reasons. Yet Europe still does not have a functioning policy to process legal migration, Dublin II arrangements remain unfair and outdated, Schengen procedures could soon be placed under new pressure and the feeding of false hopes to arriving migrants is serving to strengthen the reach of people traffickers. So, in my view, uncritical support of projects of humanitarian assistance in the Mediterranean will, while the other chapters of European immigration are still pending, serve to provoke further political and moral crises in the medium term. This needs to be reconsidered.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next point of our agenda is: Statements by the Council and the Commission on clean air in the cities of the European Union (2019/2738(RSP)).

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, air pollution directly causes both chronic and serious diseases such as asthma, cardiovascular problems and lung cancer. Ill health caused by air pollution costs the economy billions of euros in lost working days and causes 400 000 premature deaths per year in Europe alone. That is why air quality has been, and is, an extremely important issue for the Council. The EU has for some time already had a solid legal framework in place that includes the Ambient Air Quality Directives and is the basis for measures taken at national, regional and local levels. Low emission zones and incentives for cleaner transportation modes have been successfully implemented in different cities and regions in Europe with encouraging results. The data show that air quality has improved across Europe over the past decades, in particular in urban areas, as emissions of many pollutants have been successfully reduced.  In this context, let me highlight the decisive actions taken by the co—legislators over the last few months to strengthen the array of EU legislative instruments in this area even more. I think we can look with satisfaction at the results achieved with the outgoing Parliament on a number of new legislative measures that provide, directly and indirectly, important contributions to cleaner air. The Clean Vehicles Directive promotes the market uptake of zero and low-emission vehicles by introducing binding minimum targets for their use in public procurement in each Member State. These measures will play a key role in cutting greenhouse gas and air pollutant emissions and will also contribute – to an important extent – to achieving the EU’s climate commitments under the Paris Agreement.  The directive overhauling electronic tolling systems in the EU updates the technical interoperability requirements for such systems. It will create a system of exchange of information to reach foreign drivers who have not paid their road charges and fees with a view to enforcing the respect of road tolls more efficiently. At this stage it also covers charges for access to urban areas, but not complete bans or limitations to certain types of vehicles. However, the review clause of the directive requests that, by 2023, the Commission evaluates the extension of the directive to cover low emission zones, restricted access zones and other urban vehicle access regulation schemes.  Finally, let me also mention the recently adapted climate legislation to reduce CO2 emissions from cars, vans and heavy—duty vehicles that will accelerate the uptake of cleaner technologies such as zero and low-emission vehicles, thereby also helping to reduce air pollution in our cities.  The Finnish Presidency attaches great importance to the protection of air quality and to improving the environmental performance of vehicles. In this context, the Presidency considers that it’s crucial to continue the mandatory application of real driving emissions test procedures on the road and not to rely solely on test procedures in laboratory conditions. To reach that goal, the Parliament and the Council need to come to an agreement on conformity factors. As you know, the devices we use to measure real driving emissions have technical uncertainties. Conformity factors take account of these uncertainties.  We hope to reach a swift agreement with Parliament on the new Real Driving Emissions (RDE) proposal in order to ensure legal certainty for all parties involved. It is of the utmost importance to ensure the implementation of EU air quality standards by all stakeholders, an issue that is closely followed by the Commission. We know that there are still compliance gaps for some key pollutants. The Council is therefore looking forward to the completion of the Commission’s fitness check of the Ambient Air Quality Directives, which it will examine with great interest as soon as available.  Good air quality, especially in cities, has a positive impact on the quality of life for each of us. A number of cities in the EU still exceeded the limit values of the National Emission Ceilings Directive. Thus we all have to work nationally to secure better health for our citizens. The strong link between air quality and climate change means that similar measures can help to tackle both. For example, the transport sector is the biggest source of emissions of black carbon that accelerates the warming of the Arctic region. This is important to keep in mind in the EU discussions as well. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, clean air, and protecting the health of our citizens, is a key priority for the Commission. The fact that air pollution causes over 400 000 premature deaths every year is unacceptable. We have to act, to the benefit of our citizens. And that is precisely what this Commission has been doing this mandate – and we have done so resolutely. Our actions have been based on three main pillars. First: supporting our Member States in reaching EU air quality standards. We have made EU funding available under various financial streams and the Member States have successfully used that funding to address the air quality challenge. To cite just one figure: in the current programming period 2014-2020, almost EUR two billion have been directly allocated to air quality measures under the European Structural and Investment Funds. Second point: improving how we regulate emissions at their source. Prominent examples for this are the Directive regulating medium combustion plants and the package of Real Driving Emissions rules. Third and final: taking decisive enforcement action when and where exceedances of air quality limit values persist. The Commission is currently pursuing 30 infringement procedures against 20 Member States for exceedances of particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide or sulphur dioxide limit values. For two cases already, the Court of Justice has confirmed that Member States need to accelerate their efforts to improve air quality further. The Commission is doing its part, and will continue to do so as the measures taken so far have resulted in some improvements. But we also need to remember what that part is. Our legislation on ambient air sets limit values on air pollution, and an obligation to keep exceedance periods as short as possible, and the Commission steps in when and where this is not the case. But the choice of measures lies with Member States. It is up to their authorities, across levels of governance, being national or local, to define which coordinated measures they take to meet the agreed limit values. When the Commission takes infringement action against Member States, the goal is not to ensure that one measure or the other is implemented – be it a specific clean air zone, support for renewing the fleet, replacing old boilers in households, or any other measure. The goal is, first and foremost, to speed up efforts in those Member States to reach compliance with EU legislation, and to keep any period of exceedance as short as possible. Beyond legislation and infringements, we support cities in a number of ways to make their air cleaner. When it comes to urban mobility, for example, we are working with national and local authorities to identify best practices on urban vehicle access regulation schemes such as low-emission zones and traffic restriction measures, but also to foster consistency in line with single market principles and ensure information on such access regulations.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Health is our greatest asset, and that is why it is certainly our common goal to reduce air pollutants. We have already achieved a great deal, and this should not be forgotten in all discussions. On the subject of NOx, for example, since the 1990s, we have halved pollutant emissions through European Union measures and national measures, in other words, we have also halved the health burden on citizens. In the 1990s, there were very frequent ozone alarms in Central Europe. Ozone is produced by solar radiation and nitrogen oxides. Solar radiation has increased, but nitrogen oxides have decreased. That is why we have less ozone alarms. That is why it is not a cause for panic, but it is reason to act and to continue along this path. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats believe that driving bans on diesel vehicles are not a good solution, because firstly, it is a burden for many citizens who depend on the car and cannot buy a completely low-emission car so quickly. I also think it is difficult. In my country, for example, there is a threat to close a motorway that runs through the middle of the Ruhr region– a very large area of five million inhabitants. When people drive through the residential areas, health is certainly not well served. That is why we need to address the problem at source. That is exactly what the Commissioner said, and I would like to support that. A great deal has been done, but we must also make the car industry more accountable. We must offer diesel drivers retrofitting if they are affected by the emissions manipulations. Personally, I am also in favour of a new level of Euro 7. However, we must also look at other sources, such as shipping. President Ursula von der Leyen spoke about this in relation to CO2, but we must also take greater responsibility for shipping in the case of other pollutants. In German said, ships often burn the last dirt and have virtually no exhaust gas cleaning. This must change if we are to make further progress on air pollution.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! Thanks for the introductions to this topic. For us in the Socialist Group, clean air in Europe is a huge top priority. It is important for the health of our citizens to be able to breathe clean air.  I fully agree with both the Commission and the Council that much has been done in recent years. But that despite this, we have a lot of problems around Europe. For example, in Madrid and Madrid Central, which have had a challenge with their air quality and the environmental zones set up there. The air in Madrid is not clean and they want to be able to do something about it. So we see it in many parts of Europe that citizens cannot breathe proper air. We need to do more. We need to do more! The Member States have a huge responsibility because it is you who have to ensure that we comply with the rules we have. The European Commission also has a huge responsibility. In the last term of office, we had the whole 'Dieselgate' scandal that we were working on and we have got good legislation in place, but it has not yet come into force. It won't do it until next year! And that's only a quarter, I think, of the cars that drive illegally as a result of the 'Dieselgate' scandal, which has been withdrawn from the market, so three-quarters are still driving out there and polluting. That is simply not good enough! Our air needs to be cleaner. And why should it? Yes, as Peter Liese also said, it should, because it is about our health. People are dying from this. And the people who don't die get a worse quality of life. So it takes a lot more. I would like the old European Commission to ensure that the new European Commission is told that it is a priority for us in the European Parliament that something more needs to be done.  We must have looked after our toolbox. Can we, for example, allow Member States to ban diesel cars and petrol cars if they need it in order to create cleaner air and health? The aim is to create opportunities to do more in this area. This could be one of the options. I think we should help the citizens of Madrid and all sorts of other places to ensure that they can have clean air. They don't have that today. It is time for us to act.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, our cities are dying. Almost every European living in a city is now exposed to air pollution at a level that is damaging to human health. 400 000 Europeans are killed by air pollution every year, 40 000 in the UK alone. Countless more are becoming sick, and the cost to our health services and businesses runs into billions. There are some in this Chamber who deny that this is a European issue and say that the EU should not tell Member States what to do, but air pollution does not respect national borders. One country’s pollution affects another country’s people. We in the European institutions are the last line of defence for our citizens, and we must act now, decisively and quickly. Yesterday I told Ms von der Leyen that my support for her election would depend on immediate action on the climate emergency. One day later, I am calling for that radical action. Friends, Parliament established its position on clean air earlier this year. It’s time now to deliver what we have been asking for: clean air, better health, fewer deaths.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, breathing kills! Commissioner, there are not 400,000 premature deaths every year, 600,000 premature deaths every year in Europe. This is a real health scandal. We have to act fast, strong and now. Currently, there are 29 infringement proceedings under way against 20 Member States for non-compliance with air quality standards. The same states that draw no conclusions from this scandal, from this so-called Dieselgate case. For the past four years, I have been sounding the alarm. 40 million garbage vehicles remain on our roads. What did you do? What are you waiting for to recall these vehicles? What are you waiting for to remind consumers of consumer law? Air pollution exists everywhere. Does the Commission intend to take responsibility, recall these vehicles, respect consumer rights? The reality is there: you have a duty to guarantee citizens a genuine respect for the quality of their air, but above all the protection of their health. I'll just give you an idea. What are you waiting for to put in place a plan for the exit of diesel and petrol vehicles by 2030? You will gain on climate, you will win over industrial policies, but above all you will gain consistency between your speeches and your actions.

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for your excellent work. For me, as a newly elected Member of Parliament, after all the political opinions, including from the Commission and the Council, the impression has finally been confirmed: not only in the media, but also in the EU institutions, there is scaremongering rather than competence on the subject of the environment and energy. CO2, by the way, is not an air pollutant, and how you intend to measure the alleged figures for premature deaths remains a scientific mystery to me.  Like a bazaar of green-painted idiots, haggling is done. Here a little less limit value, there a new climate tax. Instead of informing citizens, political propaganda is being carried out with climate and air pollution horror scenarios, which unfortunately catch the people of many. The Air Quality and Clean Air Directive of May 2008 created the conditions for environmental zones with driving bans. There are currently 58 of these environmental zones in Germany alone. Good-faith citizens who had relied on politics and the procedures under the rule of law were deceived. After all, anyone who bought a diesel car that met the standards not so long ago must now find out that it was expropriated by the state. Because he now owns a worthless car that is no longer allowed to drive in many cities. Thanks to innovative diesel technology, modern filters and other protective devices, the air in Europe is getting better and better. People are living longer and longer. For 20 years, particulate matter pollution and nitrogen dioxide pollution have been continuously reduced. The latest data from the German Federal Environment Agency show that in 2018, not a single one of the 536 measuring points in Germany exceeded the annual mean value for particulate matter of 40 micrograms per cubic meter. In the Erfurt environmental zone, for example, the limit value for particulate matter has not been exceeded in succession since 2012.  Must the end of humanity now be postponed? Is saving the world in the water? No! If, as envisaged, the fine dust limits are halved, then almost overnight Germany, and probably as much of Europe, will be transformed into a no-driving zone, and we are thus coming quite close to the green wish of turning our country into a nation of donkey carts and cyclists. Finally, I am very curious to see how many of my esteemed colleagues and concerned environmentalists will not be taking the rowing boat to the UN climate conference in Chile in December.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, we are very sorry that the left brought to this chamber the matter concerning Central Madrid for the sole purpose of damaging Spain's image and interests, which is also quite common among Spanish Socialists and Communists. On 26 May, not only were European elections held in Spain, but municipal elections were also held. And madrid decided to vote for those parties that mostly had as their proposal the abolition of the system of restriction of movement in Central Madrid. But there is an undisputed reality, which cannot be denied, and that is that Central Madrid has been a failure: a failure for traders, who have seen their sales reduced by more than 15%; a failure for families, which take more than two hours to get to their jobs or take children to school, and a failure for air quality and improved air pollution, because in reality – as has been said here – air has no borders and air pollution levels in Central Madrid have not been improved and , however, they have moved to outlying areas of that same city. We will not accept that the left gives us a single lesson in relation to the conservation of the environment or the defense of the health of the Spaniards. But what we are also going to say is that the solution is neither to prohibit nor to restrict. Public transport will need to be improved; coal boilers will have to be abolished — more than five hundred are still in Madrid; replace oil boilers with gas boilers or incentivize renovation plans to prevent only the rich from going in electric vehicles around the city. And finally, what I do have to say is that the solution cannot happen because, in Brussels offices, a team of technicians tells Madridns how to manage their city.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, air pollution is killing. It kills 900,000 people worldwide every year. In Europe, I think Karima Delli's figure of 600,000 people is good. In France, 67,000 people die each year from the air they breathe, or about 9% of the country's mortality.  The causes of this phenomenon are known: industrial pollution, road traffic or extreme population density. As chairman of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to add that we must continue to direct structural funds towards this objective, but we must also rethink the whole urban organisation. We must also have the courage to fight against the 'all-car' lobby, because we have not forgotten the 'dieselgate' scandal.  Finally, I want to say that we still need to strengthen our actions against the refractory states that do not comply with the air quality directive, and I am thinking in particular of France which is showing very ill will.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted that this second part-session in Strasbourg is about such an important issue, because the air pollution emergency has been the subject of this House, over and over again, even in the last term of office. We have worked on an important resolution which somewhat dictates the line to be followed.  I hope that the European Commission will take on the recommendations of this Parliament during the last parliamentary term, and it is true that many of the regulations have been adopted, i.e. the one on the promotion of clean vehicles, which has already been mentioned, I am thinking of the reduction of CO2 for cars and vans and also for heavy goods vehicles.  But much, much more needs to be done, because in my country, In Italy, there are 219 premature deaths, every day, due to air pollution, ninety thousand a year, and the scientific studies that today tell us how air pollution adversely affects children's cognitive development is something very serious, which should alarm all of us, and therefore greater ambition and greater determination in introducing serious measures to combat air pollution.  On the other hand, I agree that the bans on certain polluting, more polluting vehicles such as those mentioned, diesel vehicles – and today there are over 40 million still circulating on our roads that do not comply with the rules – are to be banned and I expect greater ambition on the part of the European Commission for a coordinated recall in all the countries that are still struggling to do so. Therefore, greater ambition on the part of the European Commission.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, the fight against pollution admits neither divisions nor delays. Our priority is the health of all Europeans. Every year 400,000 Europeans lose their lives prematurely to pollution. Those who intend to politicize this debate are wrong. The fight against pollution is not a heritage of the left or any political ideology. In Spain we are too tired that the left always appropriates other people's merits and shared merits. Yesterday feminism and today the environment. Why don't you talk about Paris? Why do they talk about Madrid and don't talk about Paris? I give you an example: Madrid and Barcelona in the last four years have been ruled by the left, that left unable to put effective measures against pollution, doing so against the people of Madrid. And now they're coming to teach us lessons. If you come, come and acknowledge your inability to fight pollution. Ladies and gentlemen, there is only one way: to raise awareness, to involve all citizens, global policies with effective measures and, above all, political and social consensus. Let's not be hypocritical, partial traffic restrictions are not enough if there are still polluting heating boilers. Greater use of alternative fuels, improved public transport and renovating the car park is needed. For the People's Party, the defence of the environment and health is a central objective, in Madrid and in any city in Europe.

name: César LUENA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the right and the far-right in Spain, you have come out on the defensive in this debate. What is happening, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Madam Minister, is that Central Madrid is working and Madrid Central is a success in combating pollution and in defending the quality of public health of Madrid. And in Spain there are no health cords; that is why it governs the right and the far right in Madrid and they wanted to eliminate Madrid Central, causing more pollution and worse health of Madrid. But a judge, a judge, ladies and gentlemen, has stopped them. And I am going to read you a part of the judgment, which says: "In the face of a measure aimed at environmental protection, such as Central Madrid, the municipal agreement [which suspended it] offers no alternative to supplementing the abolition of the low-emissions zone, nor does it justify that it was ineffective or has caused greater damage than it sought to avoid on an environmental level." And the judge continues: "Protection of health and the environment are principles that must govern the actions of the public authorities." That is why, Commissioner, Madam Minister, since you have spoken here about the revision of the Air Directive, what I ask is that, when there are local governments, large cities, which implement measures at the centre of their cities, as important as Central Madrid in the case of Madrid, it will be protected and defended. And if reactionary, climate-negative governments come, they are prevented from reselling these measures. Central Madrid is a good example for Europe and for the world. We have to protect him and defend him. Let's see if you understand, lords of the right and the far right in Spain.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, the objectives against climate change are global, but the key measures to achieve them are local. Urban mobility is a great tool to turn citizen concern about climate emergency into effective emission reduction, concrete, balanced, sustainable and realistic actions. Changing mobility habits starts with yourself, but requires conditions. Cities and regions must have all community, economic and technical support in order to plan sustainable urban mobility, such as the Commission's excellent guide to planning sustainable mobility. That is the way to address long-term, integrated, evaluable and participatory policies. We need laboratories like the one that starts these months in the capital of the Basque Country and networks of exchange of experiences, and we celebrate the clear signals sent by Europe, responsible for setting maximum emissions, to whom, as has just happened with Madrid Central, they make electoralism with such a serious matter. We must work together to have global solutions from the local level.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, as has been said, we are facing a very serious public health problem, with around half a million deaths in the European Union. And the fight for air quality is not that it is someone's heritage; is the assets, in any case, of the European laws to be enforced. And, Commissioner, we have a problem with compliance with these laws which comes from the 1980s: thirteen infringement processes for excess nitrogen dioxide emissions in some Member States; sixteen, by the emission of fine particles. We have a real problem and the cities have been alone fighting this problem. Up to 231 low-emission zones have been developed in the European Union, while in many Member States – such as spain, where Madrid and Barcelona have been at the forefront of this fight – we had poor diesel taxation, the state did not invest in public transport, we did not have adequate labeling from traffic authorities... Cities have been alone doing that. What am I asking of the European Commission? I ask you basically to support the local authorities when they are brave in this fight.
