You cannot go blind when some try to close Central Madrid, when it has been a success, by reducing nitrogen dioxide emissions in the city by 17%. Be brave and defend Madrid Central against the hit-and-runs on the right.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, globalisation has, among its perverse effects, led to unbridled metropolisation and worrying pollution. Today, the formidable challenge of green cities faces an unambiatized observation, that of ever more intense pollution and an increase in human and economic flows and interactions.  Stopping this process is vital. We should de-clutter cities, intensify efforts to innovate and capture pollutants, generate virtuous circuits, in a word, re-root European cities to finally breathe. But these emergency measures must be complemented by the total reversal of the vicious spiral by stopping metropolisation and reinvesting less urbanized land to make it livable.  The fight against desertification, both human and plant, must be a priority. Bossuet said, "God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes." I wish here a radical awareness so that we contain the phenomenon of metropolisation at the source of pollution in our cities and serious damage to our health.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Health, clean air are obvious things that we do not need to be convinced of. All countries should support each other and carry out organised and systemic activities. When the government was established in 2015, there were declarations (and later concrete actions): we improve the climate, improve the air, improve energy efficiency, and ensure the eradication of energy poverty. In Poland, we are based on three pillars. Firstly, for the first time, standards have been set for boilers burning solid fuels. And these are the standards that will apply in the European Union from 2020. In addition, for the first time, the quality of solid fuels was determined, and in addition, various provisions were carried out, laws that introduce tax credits, educational programs, including the idea that educational networks of schools called "anti-smog" were created. We already have 350 schools in them.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: – Mr President, we are increasingly aware of the extent of the ecological crisis we are facing, and it is not because of European policies or leaders, as we are seeing, but by civil society organized, especially young people. 400,000 people in Europe, 10,000 in Spain and, in Madrid alone, fourteen die daily prematurely due to air pollution. In Central Madrid, this pollution has been drastically reduced. And it is a disgrace— it is a disgrace — that conservative governments, which have systematically failed to comply with environmental legislation, now want to reverse it. The European Union must avoid this. We must be brave. We must live up to the demands of the millions of citizens who are asking us for changes in environmental policies. We cannot allow this to be reversed for purely sectarian reasons. We may think differently, but we breathe the same way.

name: Bartosz ARŁUKOWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, we need to start by correcting the words that have been said in this House. It must not be said that it is not really known how many deaths have occurred in Europe due to air pollution. It is Mrs Limmer who has just said this, so such things need to be straightened out right away. Hard data says that 400,000 people die from air pollution, nearly 500,000 people die from air pollution. And it is not that we drive wooden carriages around our cities, as she said, but that we build modern, well-connected, well-built cities. And we need to support local governments, we need to support regions, social organisations that know best how to rebuild cities so that people live as comfortably as possible. And we have examples like this in Europe. Such an example is Stockholm, the first city to introduce cleanliness zones. We have cities like Berlin, Hanover, where it all works and people just live healthy and safe lives. After all, there is a city in Spain – Pontevedra, where car traffic in the center was reduced by 53%, and in the very center by 97%. And another interesting fact about this city: since 2011 there has been no fatal car accident, so we have a multifaceted action: modern, well-connected cities, which are built by their regions, local governments and social organizations.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, 400 000 people a year die prematurely in Europe because of air pollution, 40 000 in the UK. So let’s be clear at the start of this mandate that protecting public health and removing environmental risks to health should be one of our first and foremost priorities and it’s why we must demand more ambition on climate change and sustainability from Ms von der Leyen. And it is why I speak today to remind us that Brexit won’t just be an economic disaster for my country, it will be an environmental disaster as well. It is also why I stand today to support my Spanish colleagues on this side of the House in their concern and anger about what is happening in Madrid. ‘Madrid Central’ is Europe’s most successful clean air zone. We should be building on that progress and learning from that progress.  I also applaud the work happening in cities like Leicester and Nottingham in my constituency: big efforts to reduce vehicle emissions and promote sustainable transport. Finally, when positive environmental progress is attacked and undermined we must defend that progress together. The new right-wing populism we see today is a real and present danger to progressive environmentalism, so if we are serious about that better carbon neutral future with clean air for our kids to breathe, then we must speak out when that progress is threatened. We must defend that progress we are making, and we must win the argument against those who want to trash the future and who want to turn back the clock on the progress we are making.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good that we have made environmental policy a very relevant issue for the majority in this House. However, it is absolutely essential that we also talk about air quality, because a recurrent permanent exceedance of the limit values throughout the Union is really a threat to the health of the population in general. However, we also have a responsibility to do what has a lasting effect, which is perhaps also a little more complex in implementation, but above all effective.  I have already noticed that the debate here is mainly simplified. I believe that what comes from the far right should not really be addressed, because of 'no, no, no, and, by the way, globalisation is to blame', but it would be important to talk about what is effective and important and useful in the long term for the people of the whole of Europe. And that is the fact that we are expanding public transport everywhere, because if it is available, people will also change trains. It would be even more important that we have a comprehensive charging infrastructure throughout the Union, including for alternative propulsion systems. This is also something that would really make a difference across borders, and that we are finally addressing the wood taboo, because often particulate matter and nitrogen oxides also come from in front of the cosy fireplace. And it would also be important for us to talk about the limit values, because the need to introduce prohibition zones for legal vehicles actually tells us that we need to change standards.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it is true that air pollution is an invisible killer which remains the european Union's leading environmental cause of early mortality. The European Environment Agency reports, as has been said here, more than 422,000 premature deaths each year due to these fine particles. And ANSES, the health safety agency in France, is calling for a high level of vigilance with regard to ultrafine particles - I'm talking about PM2.5.  So, Commissioner, one of the first things would be to revise our two air quality directives, since they do not take into account WHO recommendations. That's the first thing. Then, of course, have the analytical tools to be able to measure them.  I share the Commission's view on the need to strengthen cooperation with Member States and local authorities by redirecting European funds as levers to improve air quality. This involves radical measures, including the end of European co-financing on polluting and climaticd road infrastructure projects, the financing of structuring public transport projects, the financing of an ecological conversion plan for polluting industry, aid and support to reduce the car's place in the city.  These are measures on these structural funds that must be encouraged.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! As a politician, but also above all a doctor, I realize how important the air we breathe is an important factor for the quality of our lives. However, this issue is complex because the Competences of the European Union in this area are limited. In particular, EU law does not require the introduction or restricting of traffic zones, and such decisions are left to local communities. Member States and local authorities have many other tools to improve air quality. More than 20 Member States today have a problem meeting air quality standards, so the problem is not confined to a single place. I think we need a more innovative approach to energy, transport and spatial planning. As a doctor, I am also faithful to the primum non nocere principle. We should take into account the conditions and wishes of local communities, because top-down solutions that do not suit them can have negative consequences in the long term.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as has already been said here, the impact of air pollution on health is of enormous magnitude. In Portugal, the available data point to a continued and worrying degradation of air quality. Lisbon is the sixth most polluted European city by cruise ships. The emissions of sulphur oxides on the Portuguese coast were 88 times higher than the emissions of cars circulating in Portugal, which are already very worrying. Lisbon is also the only European capital with an airport within the city, exposing the population to the emissions associated with them.  We need ambitious legislation in the field of air quality. We need more rigorous oversight, control, monitoring. We also need investment, which must be taken into account in the regulation and programming of the Structural Funds. The experience of several European cities that have implemented the gratuity of public transport must be assessed and replicated. Finally, we also need contingency and emergency plans for already verifiable situations of high concentrations of pollutants that call into question public health.

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Mr President, the European elections have shown that climate, the environment and health are major concerns for our citizens.  Every day we see the health effects of air pollution, with an increase in allergies, respiratory diseases, especially in children, or cardiovascular risks.  As you pointed out, the European Union has already acted by legislating, in particular and recently, on vehicle emissions or on the energy performance of buildings. However, this is not enough. Air pollution rates are still too high, legislation is still imperfectly enforced by Member States, encouraging changes in people's behaviour, insufficiently accompanied.  We must continue to take action on this issue of outdoor air quality, but also on indoor air quality. Energy insecurity, particularly in the area of heating, and the problem of air conditioning are essential subjects in this regard. While the approaches are different from one Member State to another, this should not prevent us from working on them.  We have to be ambitious, pragmatic and I think that this major issue of indoor air quality was missing in the presentation that was given to us.  Citizens expect us to take concrete, realistic actions that can be applied in the short, medium and long term, far more than big statements.  We regularly regret that citizens are turning away from Europe. It is up to us to prove to them the added value of this Union in terms of global issues, it is up to us to provide European responses and to act collectively and in a harmonised way.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, now that we are talking about pollution in big cities, here in the European Parliament, it is the good time to remember the very serious threat it poses to public health. A threat that ends up becoming the multiplication of diseases, affecting the growth of our children and meaning 400,000 premature deaths in Europe per year. And that requires drastic responses, in the form of changes in our energy, how we organize our transport and the infrastructures we have in big cities. And that is why we require from all the Administrations – European Union, Local Authorities and States involved – in this response. That is why it is the best time to denounce the shame that means that a large city like Madrid, with more than three million inhabitants, has decided to reverse a decision that is aimed at combating pollution in the center of the city with the creation of a low emissions zone. An immoral decision, because there are fifteen prematurely killed per day from pollution in Madrid; an irresponsible decision, because all the indicators, all the indicators in the city were saying that it was a newly established measure that was working; and a measure that goes against the meaning of history, because the Administrations, even if it governs the right with the far right, cannot walk into the past. That is why we are asking the European Commission and the Council to take letters on the matter and embarrass the Madrid City Council for this decision, which goes against the European Union's criteria for combating climate change and for pollution-free cities. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: "blue card" question. – Let's see, here it seems that the debate that there is is about Madrid Central. We're talking about pollution here. In Madrid he has been ruling the left for four years and in Madrid duties have not been done, since there are no optimal results against pollution. The question I want to ask you, Mr López, is: one, do you live in Madrid?, because it gives the impression that you do not live in Madrid; two, you talk about our children, do you have children? I have five, I live in Madrid; I don't have the problems you report. Tell me what the problems of the repeal of Madrid Central are and, above all, tell me if it is not possible to do something alternative to what has been the failure of Central Madrid.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. – I live in the city of Barcelona, but it turns out that I was born in the city of Madrid. In fact, a large part of my family lives there and I am concerned about what happens to Madrid, what happens in Barcelona... But don't worry: here we come to talk about what's going on in Amsterdam, Berlin and Paris, and we care about everything. And what happens in the city of Madrid and in the city of Barcelona is that the European Commission has already said, you have already said, that the situation you are living in is serious and that action must be taken. And what cannot be done is to reverse just the measures that have just been taken in the right direction. We all have to think about how we do it. But walking like crabs, backwards, sure, surely we won't solve the problem of pollution in big cities. Please, man, please!

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, the air quality situation in some major cities in Europe is serious. We have set standards at European level for concentrations of harmful particles, which is an important step.  However, the application of these standards remains a difficulty. What we found from a specific case: Romania was referred by the Commission to the Court of Justice for non-compliance with these standards. Sanctions, even very large, cannot unlock the substantive problem. We have an acute lack of expertise.  To improve air quality, for example, large investments in the city's transport infrastructure are needed. For years, projects have stagnated. My proposal is to hire teams of experts from the Commission to provide technical assistance. We need to take local and national authorities by hand to make progress. I propose that we change the approach and think of a device in this regard.

name: Gina DOWDING
text: – Mr President, air pollution is causing nothing less than a public health crisis. New research shows that worldwide, air pollution is now killing more people than smoking, and while poor air quality affects everyone, the burden of disease is highest among the poorest. In the towns and cities of the north-west of England – my region – more than 2 000 deaths per year can be attributed to air pollution. So we must radically transform and implement technologies and clean energy in transport, industry and heating systems. The Green New Deal makes all this easily possible. Let’s shift to a green travel system, investment in cycling infrastructure, walking-friendly streets, public transport and getting the polluting vehicles off our streets. With an active, sustainable travel system we can improve air quality, increase the quality of life, and save lives of citizens across all of Europe.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The fight for clean air is absolutely very important, and no one here in our House is discussing it, and none of us dispute that. Of course, the air in cities is particularly polluted. How specifically can we improve air quality? Let us focus on sustainable transport, on electromobility, on improving the energy efficiency of buildings or on the development of district heating in Member States with low winter temperatures.  But, I ask you to fight for something, you have to start with yourself. Let us look at the functioning of the European Parliament. Is it for the sake of environmental protection that Parliament moves from Brussels to Strasbourg for three days? How much we pollute our air with this movement! Do these car cords in the parliamentary building waiting for MEPs pollute the air or are they irrelevant? Maybe first, in order to demand from others, you need to start requiring yourself? We use slogans, programmes, restrictive objectives, and in the meantime we contribute to air pollution ourselves, this time in Strasbourg.

name: Alexander BERNHUBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. I am very pleased to be making my first speech here in the European Parliament on such an important issue for my generation.  We, the young, are the victims of the failures of recent years, and it should also be said that many climate romantics here unfortunately want to solve the problem of bans on diesel vehicles or the creation of car-free zones in cities. However, such measures are not always acceptable, especially for the rural population, which is often a major problem, as a car is the only means of getting into cities. Instead of an EU banning culture or hypocritical delusion of control, we really need incentives for climate-friendly technologies here. The promotion of alternative energy sources, as was also mentioned yesterday by Ursula von der Leyen, must be a Europe-wide priority.  Electromobility, or the enormous potential of hydrogen, must be better advertised and made affordable for all. Successful models such as e-scooters, which are already very popular in many large cities, must also be further developed, and this also requires the necessary legal certainty. Of course, we must not forget public transport, which provides the basis for further good measures. Let us stop talking about constant bans and sanctions, but let us look to the future, how we can work together with future technologies to make a significant contribution to better air in cities.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Mr President, Ursula von der Leyen yesterday pledged to achieve a climate-neutral Europe by 2050. This also means that low-emission zones will have to spread to European cities at a faster pace. Low emission zones have proven themselves and have proven to bring a number of health benefits to urban residents, including in the form of lower respiratory disease incidences or reduction of mortality. These are therefore effective measures. Unfortunately, they solve the problem of highly polluting cars only partially by de facto pushing them into other urban areas. At the same time, they entail higher costs for specific cities in the form of stronger support for public, pedestrian and cycling transport, the construction of parking lots and overall regulation of parking policy. However, at these costs, cities in all the Member States of the European Union do not have sufficient resources in their budgets, and I would therefore ask for the future to look for an opportunity to find resources to support, say, faster construction of either parking lots or alternative transport options.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: Mr President! One of the most traumatic experiences for a parent is when one's children are sick or need to go to hospital. So imagine having to go to the hospital with your daughter several times a year because Europe's politicians have not acted. Nine-year-old Ella Kissi-Debrah lived with her mother and siblings 20 metres from the South Circular, a busy road in London. In just three years, she was admitted to hospital 27 times. In 2013, she died. The coroner concluded that her death was a result of the severe air pollution in London.  Camilla Appelgren, an environmentalist, mother and former candidate for the European Parliament lives in Malta. This year, she had to send her children away from Malta so they could breathe clean air so that they would not have to be hospitalised again and again so that they would not suffer the same fate as Ella from London.  It simply cannot be right that our children's lives are destroyed by diseases caused by air pollution. At worst, our children die because we don't act. In my city, Copenhagen, local politicians are fighting to get the tools to keep the children there clean air. Between 20 and 30 cases against 20 Member States show that the current system is not working. Dear Commission, dear Council, help this Parliament to be the European Parliament that acts, the European Parliament that helps our citizens and local politicians to put an end to this invisible killer of children and adults.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: – Mr President, I am honoured to give my first speech in this house of European democracy. I come from Stuttgart, a beautiful city in the heart of Europe, but we struggle with air pollution. Stuttgart has the highest pollution of NOx in Germany. This leads to premature death and especially elderly people, pregnant women and children are at risk.  Some Conservatives in this Parliament want to lower the standards for air quality. In Stuttgart, some want to change the location of the measurement stations. This is not how it works. If you want clean air, you need to start designing cities for people and not for cars. Our local communities need support for their sustainable urban mobility plans. This should be a priority when deciding on the next Union budget. In Europe, you have the right to a healthy environment and we need to deliver on that promise.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, urban clean air zones bring some improvements in air quality, and scientific studies confirm that it does bring health benefits. But by creating these zones, mayors and councillors are struggling with a problem that is far larger than any city and transcends the boundaries of each of them. They are fighting because national governments, including the Czech government, are failing to address the problem of air quality. At the same time, these zones face various difficulties that threaten their continued existence. One of them is that they are becoming the subject of political struggle. It happens that the newly elected mayor stops collecting fines for violations of the rules of clean zones, and his decision is subsequently challenged in court, which overturns his decision and orders the re-collection of these fines. For air quality, such an outcome is undoubtedly a win, but if these legal battles were to be repeated, the fate of these zones could be highly uncertain. A weakness of the zones is that they are often politically contentious and therefore vulnerable. The systemic solution should consist, on the one hand, of tightening EU air protection legislation and, on the other, of ensuring that car manufacturers bring their vehicles into line with existing emission regulations. It is clear that we will not have really healthy air in cities, or at least hope for climate stabilisation, if fossil fuel-fuelled cars drive on city roads in large numbers. We must therefore gradually refocus on electric vehicles and keep cars away from urban centres.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Mr President, Dear Commissioner, the Air Quality Directive is fundamental for the lives of citizens and for the preservation of biodiversity.  However, in Portugal, the country where I was elected, there are several infringement procedures for non-compliance with this directive and what we see is that the Portuguese Government and successive governments have not met because they have targets that are not the most reliable to guarantee the achievement of these objectives. And what we want is to really rethink not only the issue of motor mobility, but especially aviation-related mobility. In Portugal, in Lisbon, we have the airport in the city center and an airport is built or expected a few kilometers from the metropolitan area of Lisbon. It is essential that the European Commission looks with an eye to this problem and reformthis directive so that it is more demanding and that Member States can comply with it and, if they do not comply, be pressured to do so.

name: Ljudmila NOVAK
text: – Dear President-in-Office! No air, no life, bad air worsens quality of life, harms health and even shortens life.  The resolutions and directives adopted on this subject set out many causes of unau clear air. There are also many possible solutions and measures, and the question is to what extent and time we are able to implement them. The programme of the President-elect of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, is ambitious, which is right and good.  The priorities of the Finnish Presidency were presented today. It has been stressed that the European Union must become a leading force in this area and also reach a broader agreement on climate change and the environment.  The issue is complex and needs to be tackled at several levels and in several sectors, both within the Member States and also within the European Union.  Some metropolitan areas have a well-regulated public transport network and a network of cycle routes, and the financial aspect must continue to be encouraged to do so, and the financial aspect is also important for the realisation of the projects. Investing in new technologies is promising and leads to progress. There are many challenges, and clean air is one of basic human rights. We have a lot of work to do to get better air in our cities. I hope that there will be sufficient resources and also reasonable measures.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Air quality in our cities is a very important factor in our health, especially now that more and more people are moving to our cities. However, increased emissions from industry and fossil fuel fleets mean that in recent years, in the order of 400 000 people, europe has died prematurely every year. So that is twice as many as the population here in Strasbourg. That is totally unacceptable.  The Commission has so far failed to deliver credible legislation to really improve air quality in our cities. It is true that Mrs von der Leyen promised yesterday to deliver a more ambitious overall strategy to protect the health of citizens. But my question is what really distinguishes the new from the old and what makes the Commission more hopeful for the future than what has been delivered up to today.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking today about the problem for millions of Europeans: how to effectively combat the deadly threat of smog, how to ensure clean air in cities. For 12 years I have been marshal of świętokrzyskie province – one of the regions in Poland – and I know what a burden smog is on people, which kills more than 40,000 people in Poland every year. That is why in our region we have implemented the "Green Sacrilege" programme to ensure clean air within the framework of ecological, sustainable development, which concerns one of the regions with the highest percentage of protected areas. Today, together with Polish local authorities, I want to call for a solution that will restore suspended EU funding for the clean air national programme, which also has the same objective. But in addition to low emissions, transport emissions also contribute to the formation of smog. Restricting the entry of certain vehicles into cities can effectively curb smog, but at the same time it can contribute to traffic exclusion and thus reduce job opportunities for our citizens. This is especially true in those countries where the income is lower and buying a car that meets high emission standards is a big challenge. We cannot allow this to happen, so the introduction of these zones must be accompanied by the development of efficient public transport, agglomeration and the creation of car parks on the outskirts of these zones. We must also ensure the development of alternative fuels infrastructure in order to promote low-carbon technologies.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, we are entitled to clean air, but to start with the situation at home, in Greece, in the capital of Greece, in Athens. According to the data sent by Athens itself to the European Union, in the 2018 report, the concentration in nitrogen dioxide reaches 70 micrograms per cubic meter, that is to say far exceeds the alert threshold. According to the European Environment Agency, Athens also exceeds the limits on ozone, with more than 140 micrograms per cubic meter, while the European limit for ozone is 119 micrograms per cubic meter.  So what do we need to do? Start acting and implementing European directives, giving a better quality of life to everyone, avoiding disaster. Better quality of life means better fuel than a curfew on diesel cars, which actually hits the middle class; it means reliable public transport and at the same time provision for alternative means of transport, such as bicycles or electric skates, which need regulation and special protection measures. Better quality of life means electrification, motivated electrification, electrification with a significant density of chargers over short distances and tax exemptions, in order to proceed to the adoption of electrification at a sustainable cost. Better quality of life means implementing existing European legislation first and a brave policy to replace old vehicles afterwards.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, I have been elected by Bulgaria, a country with huge air cleanliness problems and related diseases. Cleanliness of the air has been a staple of my campaign and is a major pain for the people who voted for us - a particularly sensitive topic for our constituents. I therefore express my support for firm measures at both national, municipal and European level to ensure air cleanliness. However, I cannot express such strong support for hasty and particularly one-off restrictions on the movement of diesel cars, for at least two reasons.  The first is that only some of the pollution in our cities is due to road transport. Perhaps a more important reason is the continued heating of solid fuel, as well as the operation of coal-fired power plants, as well as biomass near settlements. Secondly, we cannot afford to punish citizens for being poor. No one drives a relatively old diesel car as they want it, and because that's all they can afford. And moreover, the topic of cleanliness of air is a topic directly related to the fate of coal and industrial areas, a topic directly related to poverty. Our measures must be oriented towards serious financing of clean urban environment, clean public transport and well-being, especially in coal industrial areas.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 9 out of 10 people live in environments with polluted air and 4 million die every year as a result of air pollution. It is the equivalent of the disappearance of the entire population of Ireland with each passing year.  Anyone who thinks this is a problem of developing countries or not affecting Europe is unbeknownst. Every year in Europe, they die prematurely from problems related to air quality as many as the inhabitants of Luxembourg. Half a million people every year. And the European population lives more and more in cities where pollution is higher. Pollution is making us sick: cancer, cognitive problems, dementia and diabetes are only part of the problem. And the data show that even in rural areas pollution limits are exceeded.  We need more control over air quality because what we can't measure we can't improve. We need to work as a team because this is everyone's effort. Here in Parliament, it is urgent to decide and create mandatory solutions for cities on air quality control, planning and improvement. We need to create clean emission zones in city centres and we need to make the air of our villages and our lives cleaner and healthier. This Parliament took office a few weeks ago, but there is an urgent need to decide on this matter. It's about the lives we can save.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the More than 400 000 deaths a year are caused by excessive air pollution. In addition to the human tragedy, congestion and the associated pollution also cause economic costs of EUR 100 billion per year. Many countries have therefore already introduced environmental zones to reduce pollution in cities where most people are exposed to pollution. However, if we push through climate laws that present large groups of people with older diesel vehicles, such as craft businesses, with existential challenges, the positive dynamics in climate and environmental policy threaten to quickly turn into the opposite.  We need a holistic approach to combating air pollution in European cities, taking into account the various causes of air pollution – smart cities. The development of a smart and sustainable public transport sector in conjunction with the development of cycle paths should therefore also be a priority for EU funding. In times of digitalisation, the question also arises as to whether it is really necessary for workers to commute to work on all days of the week. In Luxembourg, up to 200 000 people from France, Germany and Belgium commute to work every day. However, home office is often not possible for tax reasons. Here we need pragmatic European solutions to tax issues. But coworking offices at national and city limits can also be a solution – solutions that simplify people's lives while serving the environment. The Member States in particular are in demand here.

name: Gheorghe FALCĂ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I want to congratulate the Commission because I am a man who comes from local government. 19 years I worked there, 15 of them as mayor. I know what pre-accession funds meant, I know what cohesion funds meant, and these funds have done good things in our communities, plus they have reduced emissions. But we can also say that with economic growth, pollution has also increased due to traffic, because in my community, the number of cars has increased three times.  Based on the fact that we know that, in 2050, 75% of Europe's population will live in urban areas, in urban communities, if not large ones, we know that we will live there. Therefore, solutions are needed. We need to have legislative instruments for a fair relationship between economic development, which will not stop, and air quality, new tools for what urban planning means, for what we will see in our communities in 2050. Similarly, we need to think of a new stage in the development of air-related infrastructure.  Also in this idea of solutions, we need to go further in support of airworthiness on rivers and canals, and the Danube can be an important motorway in Europe. And because they come from local government and know what the relationship between a central government and a local government means, we need to support a financial decentralisation for local authorities in order to succeed in implementing these solutions that start at our level. One last recommendation: better relations with the Committee of the Regions since ...  (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word).

name: Barbara THALER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have heard this for the last few hours here, and we all agree: we do not want dirty air, and this approach is also a good idea.  However, serious European measures cannot be micromanagement or paternalism. We have to deal with the big issues. How can we reduce emissions across the board? What alternative fuels can we use? Above all, how can we promote joint research, for example in the hydrogen sector? For me, it is too easy to regard the classic car only as an enemy image. My mother couldn't have done without her car. Two children, one job, few opportunities for public transport. Therefore, yes, to further develop public transport, but pay attention to people's life situations. And ladies and gentlemen, please do not patronise people. Let us not dictate to them how they should live, but let us use the new technologies, let us invest in research and development! We must take people along this path and we must offer them practical and intelligent solutions.  My own country, Tyrol, is one of those regions that is particularly struggling with the issue of transport. We need common solutions here, and Tyrol also needs its European neighbours here. With the Brenner Base Tunnel, we are currently building the largest infrastructure project in Europe. But a tunnel alone is not enough. Let us do our homework at European level, implement the access routes and make the railways attractive! That would be the right step in the right direction, towards higher air quality.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Smog is one of the problems faced by residents of large European cities, but this problem does not bypass absolutely small towns or villages, especially in the winter season, when there is a heating season. Their inhabitants, which I must say regrettly, often burn various waste, plastic or other rubbish that has an incredibly negative impact on our health. As many of you have said here, environmental pollution is 400 000 deaths across the European Union and 40 000 deaths per year in my country, Poland. And among the blacklisted cities with the highest pollution, 50 are in my country. Ladies and about. Everyone here is talking about how to fight smog. I think it is not so simple – creating vehicle-free zones, especially old diesel-powered zones, is a step in the right direction, but unfortunately without education, without changing public awareness, without changing habits, and finally without financial resources, it is not possible to easily change this trend and this danger for all of us. There is no doubt that we should do everything – press governments, local governments to make this fight as effective, effective as possible, and I think, ladies and women, that the best way is also for European Union money to go to local governments, because they will deal with this problem as soon as possible, because often state-managed funds are... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, I would like to start with the following. Of course I support all measures that will allow us to leave our kids cleaner air than what we have at the moment. That is for sure. I don’t think anyone in their right mind would support polluting the air for no reason, but I have some doubts that clean air zones are the answer. It’s probably very easy to find enemies, such as the family car, to blame but, let’s face it, probably for some families that’s the only way that the family could travel from here to there. We cannot blame them and punish them for the problems that we have for other reasons.  By the way, we’re having this debate in the same Chamber that voted for Mobility Package 1 at first reading a few months ago, which includes measures like the return of the truck, which means an empty truck will travel from the Atlantic Ocean to the Black Sea for no reason. That was supported by the Greens, who are missing this debate now.  I think we should set more goals which are reachable and which do not only sound good on paper and remain on paper, but could be achieved. Probably asking for 100% less CO2 from cars means that in 10 years we will have either no cars or cars that cost 10 times more than they cost at the moment, and probably we would use horses instead of cars. I don’t think this is the way we should proceed and we should be reasonable and honest with the people and with the voters.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We hear from our children that we are living in a time of climate crisis, because this is no longer a question of climate change, but of a real crisis. A few weeks ago I protested with my daughters in the centre of Gdansk as part of a "holiday climate protest". Imagine that there are still cities in Europe where children inhale so much pollution on their way to school, equal to smoking a pack of cigarettes. Therefore, when I hear politicians who ignore the climate crisis and try to convince us that it is an eco-fantastic, these politicians are actually killing our children. Clean air is a common good. It is our common heritage. And we must not allow it to become the subject of political wars. We need to focus on education. We ourselves set a good example and change our habits.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, if only the cities were in the countryside! At least that's what many people think. A recent survey of European citizens reveals that people living in big cities would like three things: a reduction in road traffic, more green space and cleaner air. A majority also believe that it is up to politicians to take action to tackle air pollution in major cities.  Every city dweller would lose a year of healthy life because of air pollution. A year of life! Well, yes, it is our responsibility, ladies and gentlemen, to take this into account and to combat all pollution, including air pollution.  We must put in place effective measures, make the standards for fine particulate matter more stringent, then support initiatives in areas of clean air that are protected from heavy and polluting road traffic, promote the installation of well-insulated buildings equipped with high-performance heating technologies and, finally, help the less advantaged people to heat themselves better.

name: Judith BUNTING
text: – Mr President, as a British Liberal Democrat, I was elected to keep Britain in the European Union, and one of my main reasons for wanting to be here is to help protect our shared environment. Dirty air knows no borders. Poor air quality has more than ten times the health impact than road traffic accidents, and it is the number one cause of premature death in the EU. In this age of innovation and advanced technology, this is not acceptable. We can do better; we must do better. But to do that, we need more ambition and more scientific research. We need to work with Member States to enforce targeted ultra-low emission zones in our small towns as well as in our cities. Every market town, every small town has a junction or a road where the locals know that air pollution is out of control. There is a clear case to charge dirty drivers on health grounds and, as they say, we have the technology to help them stop doing that, and now we need to use it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there is undoubtedly a problem with air pollution in major cities. This is due, of course, to overcrowding, to many road transport, to the non-washing of the streets, largely to neighborhoods that are heated with solid fuel or burn second-hand clothes. In my city, in Sofia, this is a serious problem in gypsy neighborhoods, but these problems can not be the cause of the "Taliban" approach on this topic. I repeat my colleague Novakov from a moment ago, only a few months ago this hall voted on the "Mobility Package", in which he agreed, including those who define themselves as green from this part of the hall, and they agreed to return the trucks empty, to walk the trucks empty around Europe up and down. Once again, I am forced to say, for the second time today in this chamber, that this is hypocrisy. You can't claim to be green, that you're an environmentalist, and insist that a truck travel an empty hundreds of thousands of miles, burning 20 liters per cent naphtha to satisfy the interests, lobbying interests of French companies or German companies. It's a double standard, there's no way it's going to work that way. The same question is with the possibility of working in coal-burning plants. This affects thousands of jobs in Bulgaria, the Mariska Basin, in Poland. I can't, again, repeat, the "Taliban" approach of a handful of fanatics to leave people out of work. I give you the following example – in Bulgaria the industry that produces artificial chemical fertilizers is breathless because neighboring Turkey produces much cheaper because it does not meet any standards. But you can not put a barrier between Bulgaria and Turkey, the air passes and pollutes. So, Mr President, there can be no "Taliban" approach, the jobs of citizens must also be taken into account.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, you have admitted here that you are concerned with air quality in cities, because health problems cost billions of dollars. In the case of lost working hours, the amount of the aid was EUR 1 million. So cynically, you are dealing with workers, their health and the environment, because it is the European Union and its governments that are bombing peoples by destroying countries, such as Yugoslavia, Syria and elsewhere, burning rubbish and setting up businesses with the trade in pollutants and the reactionary notion that the polluter pays to continue to pollute, which incriminate the simple user of plastics for pollution of the seas by taxing him. , while the number one factor of marine pollution, shipowners are exempted and subsidised.  With the backs of the European Union and the support of the New Democracy and SYRIZA in Greece, volos, the monopoly AGET Lafarge burns garbage and pet-coke, turning the city into a gas chamber, against the will of the inhabitants, who with their mass demonstrations oppose their plans. Only the socialization of wealth and means of production, an economy and society that is not based on capitalist profit, can ensure a planned, compatible and balanced interaction of the working man in nature and the environment.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you so much for this really very important debate. It was really very helpful for putting the issue of clean air on the agenda. No doubt we all recognise that it is one of the most important environment and health challenges of our time, and our discussion today has shown that there are multiple challenges ahead of us, no doubt also measures need to be adopted at regional and local level to deal with air quality issues. But also you know well that the European Commission cannot force any specific measures, but at the same time, our contribution to the Sibiu Summit focuses on this. We have stressed the urgency of continuing our efforts in the years ahead, and our citizens expect that the air we breathe every day is of good quality and does not leave us at the risk of harm, and all of us also recognise that they expect from us as institutions – the European Parliament, the European Commission, Member States and also local authorities – to solve this problem, to find innovative ways to reduce the problem. And I strongly believe that only together we can find ways to reduce the consequences of these problems, because it’s one of the major challenges of our time.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you so much for your contributions during these discussions: they are all highly valuable. Let me conclude by recalling that improving air quality means to address a number of factors that are relevant in this respect, and it requires common efforts to strive for this objective by putting in place a variety of measures at European, national, regional and local level. The infringement procedures recently opened by the Commission against several Member States for breach of EU air quality legislation are a testimony of the importance of monitoring whether EU law in the area is being properly enforced. Indeed, we need to act on three levels: proper implementation of EU legislation; national rules and regulations; and, last but not least, provisions by cities and local communities, which makes this all very concrete to our citizens in Madrid, in Helsinki, in Strasbourg, and in all of our cities in Europe. In this way we will be able to ensure a better protection of the health of European citizens and the environment. Ladies and gentlemen, the Presidency is putting its best efforts to achieve progress in these areas, and together with Member States and the EU institutions, we need to decisively pursue EU-wide efforts to foster low-emission mobility. I would like to conclude by underlining the importance that we attach to sustainability, the implementation of the UN 2030 agenda for sustainable development, in line with the motto of our Presidency, which is: ‘sustainable Europe, sustainable future’. So thank you all again very much for this opportunity to speak and for your attention.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed.

text: . – I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 7.17 p.m.)
